postDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2018
reviewBody: I bought one at Gamestop and the left joystick stopped working after a few months. I sent it back to Nintendo under warranty thinking it was a fluke and bought another one while it was being repaired. The first one came back and worked fine but then after a few more months both failed, out of warranty. The problem seems to be the ball cover of the joystick top rubs against the round opening of the case and creates all sorts of plastic dust that gets into the joystick electronic switches and causes them to fail. I opened up the case, blew out the electronics and it worked for a little bit but then the problem came back, even though I kept the joystick top clean. I tried isopropyl alcohol to flush it, vacuumed it out and it worked afterwards for a week of heavy use but then failed again. I was quoted $25 or $29 to repair. But instead I bought a third party one and it has worked longer than the other two and continues to work. Until they fix this design flaw don't throw your money away. Shame because when it works, its smooth and responsive and has a very nice feel.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2017
reviewBody: I purchased this when I ordered Super Mario Odyssey because my original Grey Joy-cons suffer from the notorious connection interference. This controller is absolutely amazing! It stays charged for a really long time especially compared to the PS4 controllers. I haven't quite expereienced the claimed "40 hour lifespan" that is advertised on the box but it is well over 30+ hours. If you prefer a traditional gamepad as opposed to the joycons I couldn't recommend this enough. It supports amiibo and features motion controls that can still be used in a range of games. postDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2018
reviewBody: I bought this thing because the joycons that came with my console started having issues that recalibrating was not fixing. I was so used to playing with joycons after a year of only using them. They were very comfortable as a controller in their own right, with or without the shell. I still want to get the joycons repaired or replaced someday when I get more multiplayer games/It took me a day to acclimate to the new controller, but it already feels just as, if not more comfortable than the joycons in the joycon shell. It's heavier but not uncomfortably so, it's comfortable to grip for a few hours of gameplay. Most of the buttons have decent feedback. The battery seems to be almost as good as the joycons were, I got mine last week and still haven't had to charge it since the first day.If I had any complaints, it's that the home menu and snapshot buttons are in an awkward location and don't have any good feedback, as they don't protrude out at all. I used to be able to take a video recording in the middle of a Splatoon game without getting pulled out of the action, but now it feels like I have to stop the action to reach the button.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2018
reviewBody: I used my Wii U's Pro Controller so much that there is heavy wear marks on the analog stick hats.When I bought a Switch, I saw the price tag of this controller and thought it was ridiculous. A gamer friend chided me, telling me I'd eventually get the Pro Controller.I got a Mayflash NS adapter and tried syncing my XBox One controller and Wii U Pro Controller to the Switch. It worked, but the controllers either suffered from large analog stick deadzones, and/or incorrect neutral point settings on the analog sticks. In frustration I shelved the adapter and just used the Switch's side controllers with the included controller bracket.I have large hands so the Switch's side controllers were awkward to use. After about a week, I caved in and got this Pro Controller.As the same friend said: "Nintendo sure knows how to make a good controller". The fit, finish, and battery life of this controller is AWESOME. I've been binge playing Payday 2 with said friend plus another friend and even during long weekend gaming sessions, my hands aren't sore or cramped thanks to this controller's ergonomics.So is the price of this controller justifiable? In my case.... It was. But I gritted my teeth as I placed the order here on Amazon. As I've said in the past, Nintendo sure knows how to get me to open my wallet. I don't think you'll need this controller if the Switch is mostly played by children. But teens and adults may find the ergonomics of this controller too good to pass up.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2017
reviewBody: I figured I'd be happy with the stock Joy Con controllers in the handle. postDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2018
reviewBody: I bought my Switch last year for Christmas for me from my husband ♥️. I love playing the Zelda games.The Joy controls took a little getting used to. postDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2018
reviewBody: I have been a Nintendo Switch owner for almost a year, and while I love the joy-con controller and grip overall, sometimes I prefer a more reliable and "traditional" controller. I finally picked this controller up on amazon this week. I love it. This is one of the most comfortable controllers I have ever used, which increases the enjoyment of my Switch games even more. The battery life is good, the layout makes sense, and it has built in motion-sensors for gyro-scope aiming, which comes in handy for games like "Splatoon 2" and "Zelda: Breath of the Wild." The only major downside to this controller is that the button layout for the "pause" and "home" buttons took a while to get used to, partially since the color scheme can make the buttons look similar. Other than that, I have no real issues with this controller; the battery life is good, and the controller itself is very comfortable, maybe matching the Gamecube controller as my favorite Nintendo controller. I would recommend picking this controller up for your switch. I spent months playing hours of Zelda: Breath of the Wild but worried about the stability of the controller I was using to some extent. Now I can comfortably sit back and play Breath of the Wild for even more hours on end with a controller that feels great! The controller is a little pricey, but more than worth it. So pick it up, and enjoy many hours of fun and comfortable gaming!Peace,Dana

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2019
reviewBody: This controller is fantastic at first, but is destined to have problems. Know that if you buy a Pro Controller, chances are, you WILL have problems down the line. It's such a bummer that this is a common issue among Switch owners. I take great care of my things, and my Pro controller has 2 significant problems after about 6 months of use.1) Left stick issues. When pushing the left stick upwards, the controller experiences what I've been calling "reverse drift" -- it pulls the input down. I've calibrated dozens of times, and this fixes the issue momentarily, but it always comes back.2) R-button issues. The R button's input works OK, but only if you push the button down with a bit more force. If you're playing a game that requires holding down the R button (like checking the map on Hollow Knight for example), the button will lose input unless you're really pushing down.This is my 3rd Switch controller to give me issues. I have 2 sets of Joycons that experience joystick problems as well. I love my Switch and am super bummed by their controller issues.It's worth noting that this controller is pretty expensive for the issues it experiences. I've had multiple DualShock 4s for years, with much more playtime on them, with no issues. Same with Gamecube controllers -- some of which I've had since the early 2000s. This is simply unacceptable for a company of Nintendo's stature and a controller of this price. Please Nintendo. Please fix this. Fix your Joycons. Fix your Pro Controller. Thanks.

name: Emil Borchert

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2018
reviewBody: Where to begin...I've always been fine with the Joycons, Handheld mode, in the grip, or one in each hand. I don't mind any of those control methods, nor do I find their D-Pad buttons to be a problem. But I bought this controller for Smash Ultimate and to see what all the fuss was about, because I don't want my Joycons breaking in a moment of carelessness.I thought the Joycons were solid enough for the most part, but this thing, you could practically crack chestnuts with it. From the minute I opened the box and took it in hand, I thought "this isn't the prettiest thing I've ever seen, but this thing is sturdy!"I charged it up right out of the box, played a bit with the wired connection (haven't had any lag problems at all in Wizard of Legend with it) and it finished charging from the Switch dock in a couple hours. Over the next month, I played with it every day when my Switch was docked (I just stopped taking hte Joycons off the main unit when docking it since getting this). It took, with about an hour or more of play per day, maybe a month before I got a "low battery" warning from this controller.Analog sticks are definitely taller, and face buttons are definitely bigger than the Joycons. That felt a bit odd at first, but I can switch between this and the Joycons/handheld mode for any game I own without trouble. The only difference I had to get used to is the placement of the + and - buttons; rather than being above each thumb as on the Joycons, they're between my hand here.I've had no troubles with the D-Pad, and find I rather enjoy it. Got this thing back in April, and have had no troubles at all with either analog stick or the D-Pad. (Which registers up, down, left, right, or diagonals only if I press them- no false positives at all from my Pro Controller.)Reads Amiibo just fine, I place them in the center of the controller to scan them in after I remember the right thumbstick does nothing .This is an entirely optional purchase for me, especially as I've always been more of a handheld gaming man, and am perfectly fine with the Switch's provided controller setup. But the Pro Controller is the best-feeling thing I've held that I can recall, as far as gaming goes. (Note: I've owned Game Boys, DSes, the Gamecube and Wii, and the Logitech Cordless RumblePad 2 for my PC, and that's basically it besides the 8bitdo NES30 Pro.)I have no fears of anything ever breaking this Nintendium-forged artifact, and it still looks as new as it did out of the package down to minute details. Also, the battery is massively overkill- I love it.If you think you'd like one of these, and are okay with whatever the asking price is at the moment, go right ahead. You can use it with Windows and Android phones or tablets as well, so if this controller lasts as long as my old Logitech has, $70 should average out to maybe pennies per month, especially since it works with a bunch of different machines. Planning to keep it until it wears out decades from now.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2017
reviewBody: This is probably the most comfortably designed controller I've ever held. The buttons are nice and big and feel great to press, the weight is good, the sticks feel great, like all Nintendo analog sticks do. HD rumble and motion controls work fine and battery life is worlds ahead of the PS4 controller. The D-pad is a step down from typically Nintendo design though, having no ball underneath the center, so every direction can be pushed in at once, which can occasionally cause problems, but I've played a ton of Tetris and shovel Knight with it and it's still pretty solid. The erganomics are stellar though, to be sure. Feels better than any other controller that I can think of and I think the Xbox one S controller is pretty top notch comfort-wise. Also, with the right Bluetooth controller adapter it can be used on the PS3 and aside from the six axis crap not being present it works perfectly. postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2019
reviewBody: If you are a switch owner, this is a must have controller. This is probably my favorite controller of all time. The way it fits in my hands, it becomes a part of you. The buttons are clicky and the directional pad is much better than using the joycons. The battery life is amazing and it charges quickly through USB-C.If this worked cross platform fluidly, this would be my go to controller for all video games. It's very similar to the Xbox One controller, but the grips are a little bit thinner and I'm just able to get a more solid grip than the Xbox One controller.After months of use, it still works and feels like new. The construction is solid and there's no flex in the plastic when you grip it tight during intense moments. I've gone through probably 3 Xbox one controllers because the plastic starts to squeak after a few months of use and the buttons become unresponsive. So Kudos to Nintendo for continuing to make quality controllers.The NFC tag works nicely for scanning amiibos if that's your thing.One warning, and this may have been fixed with a controller update, but after not using one of the controllers for a few months, the battery drained and would only worked while plugged in. Even with charging for a few hours, it wouldn't charge. I decided to just leave it charging for a few days (using the provided Nintendo USB C to A charger plugged into the switch) and it worked again. The battery is the same as the 3DS battery and I guess when those are drained, they take a long while to charge. So for anyone whose controller won't charge, just try leaving it charge for a day or so!

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2020
reviewBody: UPDATE MAY 2020: Not that badSo after I wrote my initial review, I was able to get the stripped screw off (and destroyed the grip in the process, having to order replacements from ebay). Then over the ensuing months I tore apart the controller probably 20 times, trying different variations of the tape trick to fix the D-pad with varied success. The tape did largely correct the false inputs, but at the cost of sometimes not registering button presses. In the end, I decided to take off all the tape and use it as it was originally designed to be used, and guess what? It isn't all that bad. Sure, when you do the input test in Switch settings it registers LOTS of false inputs, but this is less noticeable during actual game play. Now granted, I'm not a professional gamer, but I used the D-pad extensively to play Rayman Legends and Super Mario Maker, and it worked just fine. So in conclusion, yes, the D-pad is far from perfect, it's a major blemish in an otherwise perfect controller and a disgrace for Nintendo, but NO, it is not as bad as everyone makes it out to be. It's probably still the best Switch controller out there at the time of writing. My advice is to buy it and spend some time actually using it before buying into all the negative hype and trying to mess with it. It really isn't all that bad. (with regards to my original review, everything I had said about the design and ergonomics still holds true, even with the aftermarket replacement grips I had to install).------Original review:First off, this controller looks and feels amazing. It's probably the most ergonomic controller I've ever held, and *almost* everything about it feels extremely well-built. But I say "almost," because there's one major inexcusable flaw that just ruins it for me, and that's the D-pad. If you do a quick search, you'll see that this has been an issue with Pro Controllers since the very first model. The D-pad is way too squishy, and registers incorrect inputs when you move between directions quickly. It just blows my mind, how Nintendo, the company that INVENTED the D-pad can get away with making such a poorly designed sub-par one and putting it inside their Pro controller. There IS a fix, but it requires opening the controller and putting tape on the chip. I attempted it, but ended up stripping one of the screws and now it'll be impossible to ever open it up. So I'm stuck with a $70 "premium" controller with a D-pad that's so imprecise that it's borderline unusable. If playing games with a D-pad is at all important to you, save yourself the headache and frustration and buy a PS4 controller and an 8bitdo or Mayflash receiver. I used to always prefer official accessories going all the way back to the NES, but sadly, this whole experience has made me lose faith in Nintendo.

reviewBody: ...the Directional Pad is *very* subpar. If you're only going to use it for accessing features or items like in Super Mario Odyssey or Breath of the Wild, it works just fine. postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2021
reviewBody: So I've had this Pro controller for a month now and felt I'd been hands on long enough for a full review. Gotten about 150hours on Monster Hunter Generations and played a little Breath of the Wilds,I'm coming from 30+ years of gaming experience and have used every leading console developers (Nintendo, Sega, Microsoft, Sony) 1st party controllers since NIntendo Entertainment System onwards to today. I've owned many, but have used all of them extensively at some point. I've been on PS4 extensively since lunch, easily putting 2k+ hours a year, and 3k hours on Monster Hunter World since launch. So PS4 controller is my most relevant comparison now so you know were im coming from.So firstly, I consider the Pro Controller to be a big improvement over the standard Switch Joy Cons. The Joy Cons ar3 just way to small, right Anolog stick in particular hurts my average sized hands after 30min of use, and button spacing isn't great. To be fare, there Controllers ment for a handheld and in that space they do there job reasonably well. So if you want a more traditional Controller for couch gameing, it's the Pro or a GameCube controller clone, and the Pro is probably a better choice assuming you need motion controls.The Switch Pro controller isn't terrible for sure. Size is fine, maybe slightly small, but decent for average man hands and probably great for smaller hands. But immediately I noticed the Anolog Sticks aren't great. The press function is too tight, Anolog placement feels off and need to be about 25% bigger. I've heard ALOT of stick drift issues, but a month isn't long enough for that to be a issue. Face buttons fell a little mushy, no click or feed back at all. And the face buttons are raised far too much, makeing simultaneously pressing two buttons inaccurate. The ZR/ZL triggers aren't variable at all, this could be particularly frustrating on a racing game, as it's either full or no throttle. I don't mind them not being variable since I play RPGs mostly, and they feel responsive. However the L/R shoulder buttons are awful! They drop inputs frequently and sometimes don't register promptly. Unfortunately many games use shoulder inputs frequently, Monster Hunter GU being a strong example of were this is a issue. It seems to be because the actual button press happens on the outer edges, meaning to get a responsive touch you need to hold them with fingers in claw like hold. This causes alot of finger fatigue on medium sized hands and surely far worse on large hands. 4 way D-Pad is fine, and probably better than PS4 controllers. I've also noticed the left grip moves slightly already, the grips are separate pieces and shift slightly. They don't feel like there breaking, but it's unnerving to have this in 30days. Finally my biggest gripe is there is absolutely no 3.5mm standard headset inputs on the controller, and I've been told USB-C inputs don't work either. So you still need to use the Switch 3.5mm input for a headset. This is 16years behind other console devs, and is completely unexeptable in the age of online gaming.3 stars I'd is very fare, it's not terrible and unfortunately is probably your only choice for a traditional Switch controller. But aside fantastic battery life and decent ergonomics, it well below what I've come to expect from Sony and Microsoft since lunch of Xbox360 in 2005.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2021
reviewBody: So we just got these the other day, so this isn't a review on their longevity. However, we absolutely love these controllers in comparison to the joy cons. These are SOOO much better.We've been playing Age of Calamity in 2 player mode, and it was a huge pain and no fun to do with the Joy cons. These controllers are worlds better. They are a little big compared to a PS4 controller, but a better shape than the combined joycons.They have a nice heft to them, and they're rechargeable. A lot of the 3rd party controllers for the Switch weren't rechargeable, and most, if not all, were not compatible with amiibos. If amiibos matter to you, it might be worth noting that the PowerA controllers and other 3rd party controllers probably aren't compatible.As for their charge, we charged them straight out of the box, played with them about every night for the past week and they still have a charge to them. I can't really quantify that in hours, but they definitely seem to last longer than our PS4 controllers (which are a couple years older to be fair).Last point of note is the button mapping. Trying to play Age of Calamity with 1 joycon per person, the buttons on each controller is limited, and the button mapping was confusing and aggravating. Having a controller or complete set of Joycons per person is really the best way to play, and it's definitely less aggravating. I'm not the best gamer, so when the button layout became too confusing with the joycons, I just ignored the confusing buttons (which in this particular game included the button to heal yourself).Last points of note is that they do come with their own charging cords, which plug right into the side of the Switch docking station for easy charging. They are a Type C cord, so most phone charges would probably work as well. And they don't have a spot to plug in headphones or a mic, but neither do the joycons.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2020
reviewBody: This is a Great Controller albeit at a price that's harder to swallow.I bought this alongside 8BitDo's SN30 Pro+ and both controllers have their pros and cons...Switch Pro ControllerPros- Good build quality and feeling in the hand- Great comfort and IMO the best layout of inputs- Ridiculously long battery life- All the features you already know for being a Nintendo controller made for the switch. (NFC, HD Rumble, wake up the console).Cons- the D-Pad feels like an afterthought. It is prone to unintended inputs and it's location is not optimal for 2D games or platformers- for the price, it should get better warrantyIn comparison the SN30 Pro+ is miles ahead regarding the D-Pad.It has many more connectivity options, the battery is both rechargeable and removable AND it allows for AA batteries to be used instead. The rumble is "regular" but it feels actually very good with different intensities.The main downsides are lack of NFC and inability to wake up the switch, but I mainly use it for pc anyway.Overall I am completely pleased with both devices and the Switch Pro Controller is the one to get if you only need one for the switch and also if you enjoy 3D games more than 2D or platformers.But if you need a controller for the Switch than also works great with PC, Android and Mac, the 8BitDo's SN30 Pro+ is the best hand down.4.5/5 for both

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2018
reviewBody: I got this within a week of buying the Switch, and probably the one piece of advice I heard from everyone is "just buy the Pro Controller from Nintendo". The motion controls are probably the biggest here - I didn't realize that games on the switch actually depended on the motion controls, which I really missed out on when I had a third party controller. With this, there's so many opportunities for motion control to provide a natural third joystick, especially in games like Breath of the Wild. Works fantastically. My only gripe is that, since it is so convenient, I love to just throw it in my backpack with my switch and its case, and go out for the day. I would have loved to see easily detachable thumbsticks, or some kind of bumper, so that I can quickly store + access the controller without needing a protective case or worrying about the condition of the joysticks getting jostled. The battery still last 40+hrs, and only takes 2 hrs or so to recharge. Its durable as hell and holds up great. Buttons and stick still works like perfect. And I have used it for 100s of hours since purchase. A mist have even for the money wont.buy anything but from now on.( I've said that 3 times today but man, I've bought some good stuff)my 1st pro controller was the 30$ version amazon offers here n now. I wore it out very quickly once I started playing fortnite.You get what you pay for. This controller is FKIN amazing.. the smoothness the control and feel of buttons and the controller itself.in your hands is like holding liquid gold. I absolutely must insist that you spend the money and get this pro controller. It will make you a pro all the way around.Must have for all gaming shooters will see a huge difference between brands. PromiseI will update as needed to see how long the controller will last. I see alot of review complaining about left stick after a short time... I will let you know as it happens and my.use will not be lite.
reviewTitle: Must have controller, best one in 30 years I swear by it
name: Full, Honest & Tested Reviews.  FREESPEECH is imperative for FREEDOM

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2020
reviewBody: This is a great controller, in my opinion it's worth the extra money to get this over the other aftermarket switch controllers, much more comfortable than the joycons, but still a little too small for people with large hands, you'll find yourself with one finger covering the shoulder buttons instead of two like you could comfortably do with an Xbox or PS4 controller. This is technically compatible with PC but you will have to use it wirelessly, and due to some odd bug the gyro glitches out the DirectInput controls if you have this enabled in Steam... so you have to manually choose between DirectInput OR steam, can't do both at the same time, with that said you'll still want to have an XBOX controller on hand for the occasional PC game where you find yourself wanting a controller. Otherwise this is great and a must have if you want to play really long games on your switch like Xenoblade or FE3H.
reviewTitle: Great quality controller packed with features, OEM is worth the extra money
name: DC5V

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2018
reviewBody: I really do enjoy this controller. It feels great in your hands, and I like the weight of it. It's basically a better-feeling version of the WiiU Pro Controller, for anyone who's used that. 70 dollars for it is way too much though, especially when part of that price tag has to do with it having stuff like 3D rumble. Unfortunately, it's pretty much mandatory if you want to play your Switch locally with friends, or even if you just want to play by yourself on your TV. (The joycons are fine as the tablet's controllers, but they're not great when you disconnect them to play on the TV.)This controller's saving grace is that it connects very easily to a computer, making it great for PC games with full controller support. It would be much more convenient if it was XInput, but oh well.Overall, I'd recommend buying this controller if you have a Switch, especially if you play PC games as well. It isn't the greatest deal in the world, but my friends and I have gotten a lot of use out of it.
name: Amazon Customer

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2018
reviewBody: I would 100% recommend any one that has a switch getting this because the joycons are not very durable. I have had my switch for a few months and the joycons are already having problems from just regular use (I am not a huge gamer maybe play this a few hours a week). The left joycon stick is messed up and will keep inputting that I am pressing forward to move character when I have stopped this has caused me to walk off many a cliffs in breath of the wild. Get this and use it anytime you are playing in docked mode cause the joycons will just not last.
name: home cook

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2019
reviewBody: I purchased this to play Skyrim on the Switch, particularly in docked mode. Now, the Switch comes with a plastic holder that you can slot the half controls into to create a standalone controller for free. I'll call this the "standard" controller further down. So, why pay $60 or so for this?Well, in contrast to the standard Switch standalone controller, this has a very different feel to it. Because the controller is larger, the left-thumb control has a lot more "play" to it. This means there is more distance from the center to the ends. This gives me more precise control in-between the edges when using this than the standard Switch controller. And that can be crucial for some games. The standard Switch thumb control can only move a very short distance from center to end, making precise control between the edges much harder.Also, it has the vibration feature built in and a much longer battery life than the standard Switch controller. It pairs seamlessly with the Switch, and if you are using the Switch in a Docked mode, and have paired this controller, turning this controller on automatically turns on your Switch.If you find you play your Switch a lot in the docked mode, this is probably worth your money. If you mainly play your Switch in handheld mode, this isn't worth the extra cash.Also, if you do a lot of multi-player games such as Super Smash Brothers Ultimate, and feel like spending a lot of money, the Switch can pair with up to 4 of these at once.
reviewTitle: Great way to use Switch as a Console
name: C. Petit

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2018
reviewBody: Gives such a huge advantage for sport games and especially Fortnite. This makes me wanna play the switch more often. Won't leave without it.Update :After a week of using works perfectly Its just uncomfortable playing with for even 30 Minutes. The joy stick is not soft and doesn't let your thumb rest in a curve like an Xbox remote would. Plus the A, B, X, Y, buttons are really rigid and aren't smooth around the edges. All these things make it uncomfortable to play for long periods of time. Especially if your playing online games, you could find yourself playing for an hour easily.My BIGGEST DISLIKE about this is that there isn't any ON/OFF button. Everytime a button is pressed while I a bag it turns on to search for a device. There's basically no way to put this in a bag to travel with, without your battery being drained.
name: Edward F.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2020
reviewBody: At $70 (I guess they recently lowered the price to $60), this thing really ought to at least operate correctly. I mean, sure, everything on it functions as intended... except the left joystick likes to "drift" and register inputs that aren't being made... even when it isn't in use at all. Lovely.The d-pad is middling at best... there are plenty of better third-party options out there, especially the 8BitDo controllers like the M30. The Pro feels fine and all, but that drift... oh, and the placement of the Home, Capture, +, and - buttons are kind of odd, making it very easy to hit something you didn't intend to. Sure, it has amiibo support which no third-party products can have (and do we reeeeeally care?), but so do the Joy-Cons that came with the system.Overall, a pretty big disappointment considering it's the "official" non-Joy-Con controller. Ended up selling mine and getting an 8BitDo.
reviewTitle: Yes, it drifts, and No, the d-pad isn't very good.
name: Ben Gamble

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2020
reviewBody: Very disappointed. I was excited to get this controller that everyone has been praising for being ergonomic and having a long battery life. Here are the problems I found:- The thumb pads are not sticky enough so my thumbs kept sliding around and I had to put a lot of pressure to keep my thumbs on without sliding. This was tiring.- The controller is way too big. I had to uncomfortably wrap my hands around the controller and felt like I was stretching my thumbs to reach the thumb pads. (I have normal sized hands for a man whose 5’10”)- The thumb pads were too tall. This meant I had to stretch my thumbs even further.- The - and + buttons are further from the neutral thumb positions than on the joycons. Making reaching them take slightly longer.- The - and + are barely raised above the controller surface. So, they’re harder to find tactically. This is something I could probably get used to eventually.- The cherry on top for me was that L and R buttons sometimes don’t register when you push them past their “clicking” point. You have to press them just a hair harder for them to register. This meant when I was pressing them quickly in-game, that every few button presses were skipped. I don’t know if this a defect or what but. I don’t like buttons that click but don’t register instantly.So in short, the controller wasn’t ergonomic or comfortable for me. The regular joycons on a controller mount are a million times more ergonomic and comfortable for me.
name: sandwiches

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2021
reviewBody: The pro controller is pretty solid. There was flawless connectivity and almost non-existent input lag when I was laying smash bros. The setting up/ pairing of the controller to the switch is almost instantaneous and incredibly easy. VERY, VERY long battery. I tested to see how long the controller battery would last without charging it and got up to 38 hours straight, but when I broke it up into daily game sessions, I got up to a week and a half without charging it. USB-C support and HD rumble are some pretty nice features. The textured grip and textured buttons are pretty satisfying. My problems with the controller have to be about 2 things. #1, the price is incredibly jacked up, I admit it's a good controller, but 70 dollars is way too much, even more than an entire switch game. 2#, the A feels way too of to the side when playing, as well as it feels like it's jammed sometimes.
reviewTitle: Pretty solid, Flawless connectivity and almost non-existent input lag for the time I've had it
name: Nana

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2017
reviewBody: We LOVE the Switch but weren't fans of the teeny tiny controllers for two-player games. I bet they're perfect for kids but my hands are just too fat for that. We bought two pro controllers (one for me and one for my husband) and just love them. We feel like kids again, playing MarioKart after the actual kids go to sleep!
reviewTitle: We LOVE the Switch but weren't fans of the teeny tiny ...
name: Em

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2020
reviewBody: This is a very high quality controller, and though the price is pretty high, it's an investment that is one-to-one with what you expect to pay for. Thus far, I've gone a year without major problems with it, Absolutely for home and small excursions(i.e. going to someone's house for the night and returning).The controller itself hasn't had really big problems(like the dreaded Joy-Con Drift[TM]), but I did notice the trigger buttons are pretty soft, unlike GameCube or XBox triggers, and sometimes they don't pick up input, but it's not TOO noticeable overall. If you have the money, go ahead and buy it, from my account, it will at least last a full year, but I'm still going strong with it, so I might update this later.
reviewTitle: Very high quality controller, Price point Reflects What you are paying for
name: Thomas Jones

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2020
reviewBody: After about a year or two of use, the left control stick began exhibiting the infamous "drift" issue. Even when not touching the control stick, my character would walk slowly to the left in games, making it very hard to control my character precisely in most games. Nintendo told me that since my controller warranty had expired, I would have to either pay them $40 for repairs or just buy a new controller. Considering this is a manufacturing defect, Nintendo should take responsibility and offer everyone affected free repairs like they started doing for the joy-cons which have the same issue.
reviewTitle: Left control stick has infamous "drift" issue
name: Jeffrey

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2017
reviewBody: Fells a bit more traditional like an Xbox or PS controller. The joycon seems a bit too easy to click the joystick down on accident while in the heat of battle that was the main reason I got this controller and for a bit more comfort. The only problem I have with button layout is the + key is close to the Home key and the - is close to the capture button and it can be easy to confuse them or not feel comfortably certain you're gonna hit the right one while playing. This is minor though as ur usually looking to pause anyway when going for those buttons and if u hit the wrong one it isn't terrible, also u get better as u use it I'm sure. The joysticks have a lot of room for play yet don't seem to activate untill you've moved them about 50% towards the direction you're going. Then the last 50% is where u have the control to manage speed. I.E. if youre trying to walk slowly it feels like you have to move the joystick farther than you should have to before walking begins which leaves less room for control in the stride between walking and running. This may be fixable in some sensitivity settings I'll have to play around. Overall though great controller it feels much better playing Zelda with this over the joycon (which is decent itself with the grips)
reviewTitle: Fells a bit more traditional like an Xbox or PS controller
name: I2ain2thunder

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2021
reviewBody: The Switch Pro Controller is a must for any owner of a Nintendo Switch... specially when looking for a second controller to play with while the Joy-Cons recharges. It's a bit smaller than what it looks like in the pictures, but holding it in hands feels fine and has a great quality build to it. It's packaged with a USB cable for charging, which can be used for the Switch itself as well. The rumble is subtle without being uncomfortable and the battery last a good enough amount of time. The greatest aspect about the Pro Controller is the feel of the buttons, they are all smooth, easy to push without tiring your fingers, responsive analogues that don't feel loose and a amazing D-pad that I wish Nindendo would use in the Joy-Cons. For all it is worth the price.
reviewTitle: A must for when playing in Dock Mode...
name: Strider-RagnaroK

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2019
reviewBody: This controller just may replace the second-gen Sega Saturn joypad as my favorite first party controller ever. It's comfortable as can be to hold, but I have just one concern. The analog sticks rub on the face of the controller and wear the plastic down, it's white powder around either analog stick. I just hope Nintendo is going to be supporting to their loyal players in a year or so when these things start wearing out.Back in the N64 days, the Nintendo customer service number on the sticker on every Nintendo product took care of their gamers and they sent me three new N64 Analog sticks for the controllers that got worn out for free. Just the analog sticks, and I had to take apart the controllers to put them in.I've only had this particular controller for about a month and I've already had to clean off the plastic wear dust from the analog pads twice.It's a very comfortable controller, but I really think it's overpriced (same as their Joy-Cons) and I question just how durable it is after seeing this much wear and tear after some casual use during less than a month's time.I'm gonna really be upset if this expensive official controller wears out early, and I sure hope Nintendo's customer service is as good as it was 20 years ago when this control stick gives up the ghost like you can tell it's going to do.It's comfy, it's USB-C, good battery life, but the powdery wear around the thumbsticks really concern me. They rub against the controller housing and I just can't see how this controller was designed like this with the wear parts.Going to try and be optimistic, but these kind of problems typically get bad enough to warrant getting upset about right after they're out of the warranty period...I sure hope Nintendo isn't skimping on quality or product support these days.
reviewTitle: Control stick wears on the housing - Worried about how long the controller will last.
name: The Consumer's Voice

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2020
reviewBody: When I picked up my Switch a few years ago, I picked up a pro controller to go with it. Why? Because I knew that I would use it on my TV a lot, plus with bigger games like Zelda Breath of the Wild and Mario Odyssey, I knew I would enjoy them much more with a standard controller. The pro controller reminds me a little of an Xbox controller, but a little bulkier. However, after time, it really fits your hands well. It's high quality and again, awesome to use if the Switch is either your main gaming console or your only gaming console (which it is for me). I also love it for games like Super Smash Bros, DOOM, Witcher 3, Skyrim and other titles. I would say, though, with the expensive asking price, if you use your Switch mostly in handheld mode or if you are only a casual gamer, or do most of your major gaming on another console/PC, then I'd probably pass on picking one of these up.
name: Ben Kizer

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2021
reviewBody: The internet is awash with people complaining about "analog stick drift", both with the standard JoyCon controllers (which Nintendo has quietly acknowledged and is repairing for free), and also for this Pro Controller. It seems to not be very durable.Mine worked fine for 2 years of moderate use (I'm a full time business owner so don't have the same time for video games as I did in my teens), after that the left analog stick would randonly act as if it was being held down in games, and in the Switch controller calibration screen. Nintendo support informed me that the repair price would be $50, since the warranty is only 90 days.I don't know about you, but 2 years of use out of an already overpriced controller is not really good going.
reviewTitle: Great, but only lasts 2 years.Warranty is 90 days. Ridiculously overpriced.
name: DM

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2021
reviewBody: A must have for anyone using the dock to play on their television. The left grip on my unit has a slightly loose shaky feeling even from the first moment but the overall build quality and battery life makes it one of my favorite controllers, period. I would definitely like pressure sensitive triggers, rather than having them just be two additional buttons but it's not needed for any first party Nintendo games. It's usually just something I'd like to have playing any other games that benefit from pressure sensitive triggers, such as racing games.Can't imagine playing the Switch docked, again, without this controller like I used to. If you can spare the additional money and intend to play on your television or monitor very often, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this. The build quality may be inconsistent from unit to unit but it's still well worth the investment if you don't play in handheld as often as you do when the Switch is docked.
reviewTitle: Minor build quality issue with my unit but still a must buy.
name: Ryan F

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2019
reviewBody: I finally upgraded to the pro controller after much time contemplating if it would really make a difference to me. I've been using the joycons since the launch of the Switch and while not perfect I can still appreciate their design concept.The one aspect of the pro controller that had me on the fence were the triggers. Honestly, that is the one thing I really don't like about the joycons. Everything else about the joycons I can work around. Well, pictures don't do the pro controller justice, the triggers are absolutely fantastic and I certainly don't see myself ever using the joycons again when it comes to playing games that utilize the triggers extensively.Not just the triggers but everything about the pro controller is a huge step up from the joycons. The buttons are bigger, the analogue sticks give a great grip with your thumbs and the controller feels nice and snug in the hands. The material is much more friendly during longer sessions. That was another gripe I had with the joycons; after a period of time the sticks and triggers would be slippery. I managed it by having a cloth nearby to give it a nice wipe occasionally. Not the case with the pro controller, there is much more friction to it.It's a must have accessory for me and I give it a 5 star because I think it's a fantastic controller and fixes every issue I had with the joycons. I suppose if there is one thing I would change about it that would have to be the placement of the right analogue stick. Personally, I'd like it above the buttons so the two sticks would be symmetrical but I don't think it merits deducting a star.
name: demonsRendangered

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2019
reviewBody: This thing feels really well built. The controller has a good quality feel to it, plus it feels just the right weight to make it feel secure in my hands. At first it felt a little big since I had been using the joycons mostly, but i quickly got used to it. The price can be a bit hard to justify, but i paid it since I knew that it wasnt a gamble. There are cheaper options out there that might feel this good, but i knew FOR SURE, that this one would be good. And it didnt dissapoint.Pros:- Good placement for the analogs- Nice big face buttons- Nice clicky shoulder buttons (not loud)- HD Rumble- Great motion controls- Great for 3D games- Comes with a high quality USB-C to A cableCons:- Price is a bit high- The analogs have a longer travel so it can feel a bit off putting if you are coming in straight from a Joycon like i was.- Not great for 2D platformers- The home button and screenshot buttons are a bit awkward to reach while playing.Overall this controller is great for games like Zelda BotW, Mario Odyssey, Doom, Ys, Mario Kart, etc, but i don't recommend it for 2D platformers like New Super Mario Bros U, The Messenger, Axiom Verge or Dead Cells. It will function alright, and i bet after playing for a bit your hands get used it, but for me it wasn't ideal and since I have a SN30 Pro, I use that one specifically for 2D platformers and this for everything else.The battery life is certainly impressive. I used it for over a week before I had to charge it, but then I dont do heavy gaming on the most part. My only real complaint is that the home button and the screenshot buttons can be a little difficult to find while playing.Also, take into account that this thing is not really portable. Not only is it big, but it keeps coming on and scanning for the switch each and every time a button is pressed. This is definitely a controller to keep beside the dock for docked playing, and NOT in your bag for hand held or table top. One of the times i packed this and brought it along for table top playing I found it had turned the switch on while it was in the bag. Its also kinda big, so definitely keep it at home. If you want portability go for the SN30 Pro, if you want comfort, go with this.Overally I think its a great controller, my biggest gripe is the price.
reviewTitle: The most comfortable switch controller to play docked
name: M. Canales

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2021
reviewBody: I'm one of those guys who only writes bad reviews, or rarely cares enough to write good ones. I bought one of these, and I think these controllers could be the most comfortable for the switch. There is a problem with the left joystick however where there is slight feedback drift. I found this out while playing pokemon. For the first one, every once in a while when I either pull the stick all the way to the left or all the way up -- and for the second one it was all the way up or all the way right -- the controller would track briefly in the opposite direction after I released the joystick. This would foil attempts to evade pokemon, and interrupted normal navigation of the game at times. This is incredibly stupid. I'm not going to pay for this controller until nintendo fixes their pro controller lineup completely. Completely ridiculous to pay for a controller at the same price as a playstation or xbox controller when the latter almost never have errors at that price point.
reviewTitle: The smallest error during gameplay -- unacceptable. Two units tested.
name: Scalting

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2020
reviewBody: This controller is amazing. Its quality is better than both xbox and ps4 and personally I like the layout. It doesnt need batteries which is also really nice. I use it to play all types of games like super smash, mario kart, and ocarina of time and it hasn't given me any problems and makes gaming easier. The regular joycons feel a bit small and aren't nearly as comfortable when they are used without the switch in your hands. Would recommend the product even if it is on the higher price.
name: Mamoon

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2020
reviewBody: It’s so much better than the joycons. The joycons are convenient for easy transportation and multiple players, but they left one gets drift SO easily. It’s ridiculous that Nintendo hasn’t solved that issue yet (other than offering free fixes). The pro controller is much sturdier and comfortable ergonomically. The battery life lasts pretty long after being charged. I like it a lot and have no regrets spending the money to buy it.
name: Jenn

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2020
reviewBody: I thought it might be hard to get used to the controller after using the Switch built-in controllers for a while, but that was not the case. Even though it doesn't feel the same as holding the Switch unit, it feels pretty natural. It has good weight, and the feedback feels almost identical to the Switch joy cons (or whatever they are called). Haven't run the battery down yet to see just how long it lasts, but so far, so good.
name: Chuck W

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2020
reviewBody: So I’ve bought two of these, one for my little sister yet and another for my little cousin. They both absolutely love it for gaming and hated using the joycons! The controller has a more comfortable hold and I’ve tested it and the gameplay experience is great! However, my little sister’s already has an occasional south drift on one of her joysticks which is frustrating since I got it for her in August and the controller isn’t cheap. But my cousin’s is perfectly fine and bought around the same time. It may depend on the player, but my sister isn’t rough when she plays at all, so it may just depend on the controller you get, so buy at your own risk! May want to consider purchasing at a store like Best Buy or target where there’s buyer protection you can buy along with it :)
name: Athyna Do

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2017
reviewBody: This makes playing the Switch much easier. I don't have huge hands, but after two hours of playing using the Joy Con controllers (both attached and detached from the console), my hands felt stressed and a bit cramped.This controller feels like it was made of a higher quality than most and is somewhere between the PS4 DualShock 4 and the Xbox Pro Controller in terms of feel and quality. I absolutely love it and after playing for about 10 hours on it over the past week, I can say that if you intend to play Breath of the Wild or any other games on your TV that require a controller, this is the way to go.
name: Colin

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2018
reviewBody: I was torn between buying this Pro controller or another set of Joy Con controllers + grip. The latter was actually more expensive but naturally you could turn the Joy Con into two smaller controllers, accommodating more players. However, I went with the Pro Controller and haven't regretted it since. I use my Switch docked 70% of the time and this controller makes gaming on it perfect. The build quality is superb, the buttons are responsive and it just feels premium. I've been using it for about 20-30 hours so I'll be sure to make an update around the 1 month mark (which is when it seems the left joystick craps out on a lot of these controllers). If you play a lot of solo games docked, get this controller. The Joy Con + grip is definitely serviceable, but take your game up a notch with the pro especially if you play games like Splatoon 2. Highly recommended, so far.
reviewTitle: Expensive, but takes your game to another level
name: K.H.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2020
reviewBody: Didn’t pay attention that the description say “used-like new” which isn’t the case. The controller frequently inputs Right on the joystick as if I was holding it down when I’m not. If this has ever happened to one of your controllers you know it is extremely frustrating & basically makes the controller unusable in most cases. It’s unfortunate I work overseas in a remote location so I don’t have the luxury of just going to the post office to return this. So I left this review to show my frustration. NEVER BUY USED CONTROLLERS.
name: Hasan Reed

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2019
reviewBody: Was exactly what was advertised and works great with the console. One issue I have run into is when using it with any kind of emulator on the computer, the joy stick does not seem to be calibrated correctly. Using the OpenEmu emulator, during many games the character will not go into a full run forwards, and will go ridiculously fast if I pull back making them go in reverse. I do not notice this with the games on the consoles I’ve played on, so maybe they are able to adjust for the miscalibration while the computer programs just can’t seem to calibrate it totally correctly. My solution has been to switch the controls to the D-pad while playing emulated games. Overall, it’s great though, and much more comfortable than the joy-con controllers that come with the Switch.
reviewTitle: Comfortable, some minor issues with the computer
name: Michael Carr

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2020
reviewBody: UPDATE:Don't go refurbished on these in my opinion. Never was able to charge the controller. The orange light indicating charge never came on. Unfortunately have to return this bad boy.ORIGINAL:My product seemed pretty used when I purchased it from the Amazon warehouse. I'm still glad I got a first party controller and Amazon is good with their customer support.But it just doesn't have that new controller feel. I was borderline about to return it. I sanitized it and everything, but I really miss the new feeling for the extra 10$.
reviewTitle: Don’t go renewed. 1st party is nice, but used is maybe not the way to go
name: Daniel

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2018
reviewBody: Every button on this feels amazing, the controller feels very solid. And built in battery too is great. I had to get this because I sit about 10ft away from my TV and the joycons seem to have trouble at that range. This has complete solid connection and fixed my issue, but after using it I realized just how uncomfortable the joycons are relative to this. If you like using the switch docked a lot it’s definitely worth the buy. And you’ll have two controllers for split screen as a bonus. I have quite large hands and this feels like it was made for me
reviewTitle: Nicest feeling controller out of all the consoles
name: Daniel

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2020
reviewBody: This is the first nintendo controller that is less than perfect. At first I was very happy with it. The joysticks feel perfect and offer greater travel and persission when compared to the joycons. The buttons are bigger and feel great. I'm very impressed that you can use it both wired or wirelessly. However like when playing the console on the go with the joycons attached I'm feeling my forefinger and middle finger being pushed appart. With most of the weight of the controller resting on the side of my middle finger. The joycons grip feels much better in this regard. If the controller didn't start to feel uncomfortable after 45 minutes of using it it would be well worth the expence. .
reviewTitle: The first Nintendo Controller that is less than perfect.
name: George F. Serr

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2021
reviewBody: I’ve been an Xbox / PlayStation guy for years so getting a handheld mobile console, as exciting as it was, just wouldn’t feel right playing with the stock joy cons. Flawless connectivity with the switch and ergonomics to make you feel right at home on the go makes this a must buy for your switch. My only complaint is I wish this had a BYOB “bring your own battery” option. I’m not a fan of having an internal battery that once it fails, I’ll have to buy a whole new controller. I’ve noticed after it sits for a week the battery will be drained by the time I pull it out again. I would be much happier to just pull the batteries if I plan on letting it sit for a bit.
reviewTitle: Please make a BYOB option for this!
name: Jacob McCullough

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2018
reviewBody: This works PERFECTLY with hobby retro game emulators that use 3 dollar bluetooth adaptors. (ODROID XU4, Raspberry Pi 3b+)Some wireless USB devices over bluetooth are problematic in 2018, and not premier quality, including various Wii-U wireless , and some PS3 wireless... but THIS IS AWESOME AND IDEAL for 2018's "Wolfanoz 400gb Special Odroid XU4 Image" and for 2018's 256GB PiPiggies.Its also amazing quality, and worth every penny. It is fun with Nintendo Switch too, but a hobby hacked switch needs the physical remotes to get out of some jams if main unit battery drains to 0 percent and hacks all fail to let device powercharge again. So you still need regular remotes on rare occasions.I own over 50 game remotes and this is my favorite on earth.
reviewTitle: This works PERFECTLY with hobby retro game emulators that use 3 dollar bluetooth adaptors. (ODROID)
name: James M

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2020
reviewBody: I bought this thing because the joycons that came with my console started having issues that recalibrating was not fixing. I was so used to playing with joycons after a year of only using them. They were very comfortable as a controller in their own right, with or without the shell. I still want to get the joycons repaired or replaced someday when I get more multiplayer games/It took me a day to acclimate to the new controller, but it already feels just as, if not more comfortable than the joycons in the joycon shell. It's heavier but not uncomfortably so, it's comfortable to grip for a few hours of gameplay. Most of the buttons have decent feedback. The battery seems to be almost as good as the joycons were, I got mine last week and still haven't had to charge it since the first day.If I had any complaints, it's that the home menu and snapshot buttons are in an awkward location and don't have any good feedback, as they don't protrude out at all. name: david vargas

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2018
reviewBody: I have big hands, so the Joy-Con controllers that come with the Switch are difficult for me to use (and they tend to lose sync every so often, which can interrupt games). The Pro Controller is almost exactly the same size as an Xbox One controller and feels just as comfortable to me, the sticks and buttons are good quality, the battery life is great, and it charges quickly. And I have not lost sync with this controller once yet. I received a second Pro Controller as a gift, and it works just as well, giving me a lot of flexibility.The only complaint I have with this controller has less to do with the controller itself and more with how Nintendo designed some of its games to work with the Joy-Cons. Super Mario Odyssey, for example, has a few specific moves that can only be performed on the Joy-Cons because they require the Joy-Cons to move independently, which you can't do with the Pro Controller. Thankfully, none of these things actually make the games hard to play.
name: KieferSkunk

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2020
reviewBody: I originally didn't see much point to buying these, considering the Switch has a built in controller. But after struggling through games like Legend of Zelda Breath of the Wild, I finally broke down and purchased this. Wow, I have to say it made quite the difference.Even after a few spills, the controller keeps on functioning (albeit some of the buttons are a bit harder to press now).

name: Sean Jones

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2019
reviewBody: I like to play the Switch from time to time but I'm not a huge gamer. After receiving the system as a gift, (thanks, wife!) I tried using the Joy-con to play Zelda and Mario. name: Wombat

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2021

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2019
reviewBody: I originally bought this controller because I hated how difficult it was to play Super Smash on the regular switch controllers. The sticks are too small, and I feel like that whole controller is better suited for portability and smaller hands.The price of one of these controllers is HALF of what it costs to get a second set of Joycon controllers and a grip, so I was a little worried that it was going to feel cheap and unpleasant to hold. postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2019
reviewBody: I initially bought this controller to play Zelda Breath of the Wild, MarioKart 8, and Fortnite. My main initial complaint at that point was that it didn't have a headset jack like Xbox and PS4 controllers have, not a huge deal. However, when I started playing Tetris99, I noticed a new flaw that became infuriating: the d-pad doesn't work well. When you push left or right, sometimes it pushes up or down too. In Tetris99, that means you're accidentally doing to do a "hard drop" when you intend to rotate the piece. I stopped using the pro controller with Tetris99 because I was so frustrated with it. Given the price of the controller, I would think that the d-pad would be better.

name: Matt

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2020

Well, surprise, that one ended up with left stick drift after a mandatory Switch firmware update. Factory reset it multiple times and it starts to drift again within a couple minutes. Thanks Nintendo!Anyway, if you want a pro controller and do not get a generic, get the real thing. This is the real thing.
name: wil post

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2018
reviewBody: I waited a few weeks to order this, so I had plenty of time with the Joy Cons in different configurations. But for games like Zelda: Breath of the Wild I found the Joy Cons attached to the default dumb controller attachment that comes with the Switch to be a little wanting. My hands are a bit larger, so it's very nice to have a larger full controller to work with.One thing I did experience, the first time I sync'd the controller to my Switch I did have some small instances where the controllers tilt functionality was hesitant or laggy. (Example: When using my bow in BotW, it just didn't want to fine tune my targeting by tilting the controller.) But it seemed to correct itself after only a few minutes of use and I've never experienced the issue again.It also holds a charge for a fairly long time. I can go a number of days with using the controller an hour or two a day between charging. However, I cannot detail exactly how many hours of use. I simply decide that it's been a few days and I plug it in again between uses.If you use amiibos, there seems to be a sweet spot on the controller that can be a pain to find initially. It's not necessarily obvious on where that is. But once you find it and get used to it, then scanning your amiibos goes quicklyOverall it's a very solid controller. I'm glad I bought one.
reviewTitle: so I had plenty of time with the Joy Cons in different configurations
name: Endy Pepper

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2019
reviewBody: I have large hands, and I find that most controllers are smaller than I'd like (many are much smaller than I'd like). It's been years since I used a controller that I thought was large enough to sit well in my hands (Logitech used to make one that I really liked, but it's probably been at least 15 years since they stopped making it, and their more recent controllers are all much smaller). Historically, the Playstation controllers have been particularly bad. The PS4 controller is much better than previous generations, because they adjusted the shape to make it less cramped, but it's still too small. The XBox One controller is a much better size, but for me at least, it hurts my hands to use the RB and LB buttons because of how I have to twist my hands to press them (whereas with the PS4 controller, it's really easy to move my fingers between the R1/L1 and R2/L2 buttons). The Switch Pro Controller is not quite as large as I would like, but it sits far better in my hands then either of those controllers (or any 3rd party controller that I've tried in recent years), and while it's not quite as easy to move my fingers between R/L and ZR/ZL on the Switch Pro Controller as it is on the PS4 controller, it's close. So, for me at least, the Switch Pro Controller is far more comfortable than either the XBox One or PS4 controllers (or any 3rd party controller that I've found in recent years). So, from a comfort standpoint, this controller is a _huge_ win for me. No other controller is even close.I very much wish that the analog sticks were lined up like they are with the PS systems. Most of the controllers that I've used over the years have had the analog sticks on the same level, and I much prefer that to having them staggered like the XBox systems do and the Switch Pro Controller does. However, the comfort improvements with the shape and size of the controller vastly outweigh that problem for me.I have heard that the dpad on the Switch Pro Controller isn't that great, and some folks end up pressing up or down when they mean to press left or right (or vice versa), but that hasn't been a big problem for me, and there are videos on youtube which show you how to fix that problem. So, it's disappointing that they didn't make a better dpad, but it hasn't been enough of an issue for me to care.Ultimately, the Switch Pro Controller is so much better for me than any other controller currently on the market that I'm actually using it not only on my Switch, but I'm also using it on the PC, PS3, and PS4. I had to get adapters to get it to work on the PS3 and PS4, but it works, and for me at least, it's a huge improvement. If I had an Xbox of any kind, I'd get the appropriate adapter and be using it there too. Right now, the Switch Pro Controller is the only controller that I use.As an interesting bonus, the fact that the Switch Pro Controller has digital triggers actually makes playing games on systems whose official controllers have analog triggers more pleasant (even aside from the comfort improvements that come with the shape of the controller), because all of the games that I play either just treat them as buttons anyway or use them for something like the speed you run at, and I've never wanted to run at anything other than full speed, so having a simple button to press rather than having to push in an analog trigger and make sure that I press it in all the way is a really nice improvement. I'd probably feel differently if I played racing games (which apparently like to use the analog triggers for their throttle), but for the games that I do play, it's been great. And of course, if you only use the Switch Pro Controller on the Switch, then the way the triggers work is never a problem, because that's the way that all of the official Switch controllers are.So, from both a comfort and functionality standpoint, this controller is a huge win for me.
reviewTitle: The best controller on the market right now
name: J. Davis

The motion works great too. I got the cheaper nintendo corded controller trying to save money and ended up wasting money because I still had to buy the pro. postDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2019
reviewBody: As much as I love my Switch, it is hard to use the controllers while attached to the system. I bought this because I miss the feeling of a full size controller. postDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2020
reviewBody: Obviously it works with a Switch. But it also works with Steam, over regular bluetooth. reviewTitle: Works with Steam too! And Android!
name: Scott Albertine

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2018
reviewBody: The Nintendo Switch Pro Controller is a game changer (pun intended). I first thought that I loved the Joy Con controllers included with the console more than anything. It wasn't until I got the pro controller as a gift that I found out what I was missing. I fee like I have way more control over my games with the pro controller as opposed to the very small joy con controllers. The battery life on this thing is outstanding. I can play 3-4 game sessions of 4-5 hours each before ever getting a low battery notification, and they charge quickly. If you have not given the pro controller a shot because the price tag being almost as much as a game, I totally get it. I would much rather have a new game over a controller too! Once you have a few games that you play consistently this comes worth getting for sure.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2018
reviewBody: I've bought two of these. They feel great, but the left joystick breaks after about 40 hours of use from white dust that collects under the joystick. The fix is to buy a new controller or disassemble and solder in a replacement joystick costing $12.
name: Travis

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2020
reviewBody: I've had this since getting my switch 2 years ago and absolutely love this controller. I've actually lost it on a recent trip to big Bear, I'm super bummed out about it so I had to get a replacement and there was no hesitation in buying another. The ergonomics and button sensitivity on this controller are perfect and they make playing the switch a real game console experience. Definitely recommend.
name: Huyph4m

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2019
reviewBody: I really want to like this controller.The good: feels very solid, is comfortable to hold, and battery life is outstanding. No issues with wireless connection to console (though I usually play wired anyway).The bad: the d-pad is awful and it's way too easy to accidentally activate a diagonal. The joysticks cross the neutral position when releasing them from the edge; if you release the joystick while holding it against the edge, many games will read it as a slight activation in the opposite direction. This is very frustrating in fast-paced games where accurate input is critical.I would much prefer the d-pad style of the joy-cons (four distinct buttons) as well as the joysticks from the joycons over the garbage d-pad and joysticks in this controller.
reviewTitle: Solid construction, good battery life, poor joystick and d-pad quality
name: C. D. Howie

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2019
reviewBody: The pro controller is a fantastic peripheral for the Switch; many pros just a few cons.Pros-build quality, heft, overall hand feel is great-buttons feel good, just the right amount of resistance when pressing-easy to connect-long battery life-slick look, nice design-tech, HD rumble and NFC for amiibo-allows for more comfortable long gaming sessionsCons-expensive, only bought it because I had a gift card-no color options, lack of choice-analog sticks have too much travel, feels sluggish for smash bros
name: Richard

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2018
reviewBody: The controller is great. The size and position of the buttons feels natural. It also has the capability of motion controls and amiibo support. However, the d-pad is really lacking on this controller. It's so lacking that I feel like it deducts 2 stars all on it's own. The reason the d-pad is so bad is that it will completely mess up your button presses. It's not uncommon to push left on the d-pad but have it register as up. This happens with all the directions. If Nintendo fixed the d-pad, this would be the best controller of all time.
reviewTitle: Controller is great, but D-pad is lacking
name: Taylor

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2019
reviewBody: I think that this controller is the best controller that you can buy at the moment. It fits well in your hand, it functions almost perfectly (the d-pad is below average, but not awful, better than og gc controllers), has a long battery life (it hasn’t run out on me since I bough it), and has seemingly no input delay. So why don’t I give it 5 stars? Because there are a bunch of tiny things I have gripes with that don’t apply to 99% of games. I think that the tops of the control sticks are too wide, but I enjoy the c-nub that comes on the gc controllers that a lot of people dislike. I like to slide my fingers over the face buttons when mashing our of grabs in smash, and these buttons roll a little to much for my liking. The fact that the sticks also don’t have notches are good in some scenarios but bad in others (an example is when trying to do macro wavebounce neutral specials in smash; it’s harder to do them bc of the lack of notches, but much it’s easier to play shooter games like warframe and splatoon). The point I’m trying to make is that, if you’re not me, you won’t have any problems with this controller at all, other than the d-pad being bad.
reviewTitle: The best gaming controller so far
name: Nicolas Perdicaro

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2018
reviewBody: The Pro Controller is well worth its cost. It feels much more natural playing a game with a 'real' controller over the Joy-Cons with the grip attached. The only noticeable downside is that a few games don't support it at all, such as Super Mario Party and the Pokemon Let's Go games. Since I had exclusively been using the Joy-Cons from launch up until very recently, it took about a day to get used to the new sticks. They are stiffer to move, but are much more precise. The weight of the controller feels similar to that of an XBOX 360/ONE controller and it's very easy to transport. The charging cable can also be used for the Switch itself through a laptop or other USB outlet which is very useful. The controller also works with Windows, through Steam. Again, very good purchase that I am happy with and highly recommend.
name: Eli Smith

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2017
reviewBody: I love this controller. I own the switch obviously and the Xbox one and ps4 and this is my favorite controller out of all 3. It is not only a fantastic design but it also feels as good as it looks, making the long gaming sessions of Xenoblade Chronicles 2 that much more enjoyable. In my opinion it was well worth the extra 5 dollars for the looks. Also the buttons are the same "emerald green which I didn't notice at first but is a great touch. Would highly recommend this product.
name: Matt Brown

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2020
reviewBody: This is honestly the best controller I've had since the Wavebird, back in the Gamecube days. I own a Switch, but I really got this for my PC.If you haven't connected it to a Nintendo Switch in your house, you can use the bluetooth functionality to play it wirelessly on PC. But once it's been connected to Switch, you'll need a USB-C to connect it to the computer.Because of the high cost, consider it an investment. I have big hands and I tend to go through cheap XBox 360 controllers kinda fast. But this thing is much more sturdy and hasn't given me any issues after nearly a year of playing it. Nintendo wares are built to last, and this controller is no different.
reviewTitle: High Cost, but You Get What You Pay For
name: GeekOfAllTradesMasterOfNone

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2017
reviewBody: Great controller all around. Yeah it's a bit more expensive that a PS4 or Xbox One controller but I believe it's worth it.Pros-Feels awesome in the hand-It's super easy to connect to the Switch-Comes with HD rumble and NFC reader for amiibos-Battery life is outstanding. Bought this a week ago and still haven't had the need to charge it. (Advertised battery life is 40 hours or so)-Can be used for gaming in the Switch, PC and even mobiles phones.Cons- The left and right triggers are not analog, meaning that using the control for racing games is not optimal in the PC- Setting the control for PC gaming can be a bit tricky and if your PC does not have a bluetooth adapter then you won't be able to use it. reviewBody: Sturdy and comfortable to hold.Works fine on PC. While most games do not support it natively, Steam offers native support. postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2019
reviewBody: Really comfortable and battery life is great. This is way better for anyone who doesn't have tiny hands. The joy-cons are not very ergonomic and have tiny buttons. I had some drift with the joy-cons after a couple of months, but I ignored it since I just used this controller instead after I got it. If it were reliable I would recommend this, but honestly I am embarrassed that I have recommended this to anyone in the past. You're basically buying a 1-year subscription to a functional controller. If you buy this, expect to buy a new one before too long.
