reviewBody: Get the Pro Controller, you won't regret it. Perfect for Splatoon 2, Fortnite and even Zelda.I was unsure when I first got my Switch (at launch) if I should fork out so much extra for the Pro Controller. I'm not a hardcore gamer and thought the Joy-Cons and grip would be enough.... How wrong I was! I've been using the Pro Controller for over a month and I regret I didn't buy it sooner. It feels solid and sturdy. The triggers and buttons have much more feeling than the Joy-Cons. The button layout is very comfortable. But most importantly, the analogue sticks feel (and probably are) more responsive and accurate.It is worth spending another $60 for this controller, it will improve your gaming experience with your Nintendo Switch.Bonus: The Pro Controller works with Windows 10 PCs (requires Bluetooth)!
reviewTitle: Buy it now so you don't regret not buying it sooner!
name: Julian

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2021
reviewBody: The controller is expensive and, although it looks and feels more comfortable than the previous Wii U Pro controller, it still does not feel as premium as its competitors— the PlayStation DualShock and Xbox controller. I bought this controller for Smash which can be taxing on your controller, and it seems it cannot sustain much play for long. The joysticks especially feel vulnerable. The right joystick snd A button are pretty close to each other, and I accidentally press one or the other which screws up my competitive gameplay, albeit I have large thumbs. The GameCube controller from back in the day (not the recent ones), last forever. Battery life is good.
reviewTitle: Expensive, and the quality is slightly inferior to its competitors. Design is descent.
name: Takle

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2018
reviewBody: A must-have for anyone who intends to seriously play on the Nintendo Switch for hours on end. The joy-cons are an interesting concept and are sometimes fun to use, but ergonomically speaking, they're not the greatest for long gaming sessions. That's where the Pro Controller comes in and saves the day. This is a well-made controller with pretty good haptic feedback. It fits well in the hands, and has good quality buttons and texture. The battery also lasts quite a while, and can be recharged using the included USB-A to USB-C cable, which can be attached to any USB-A port on the Switch's dock, or plugged into an appropriate USB-A wall outlet or adapter.
reviewTitle: A must-have for long gaming sessions on the Switch
name: Tom C.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2020
reviewBody: Before I got the Switch Pro Controller, the Xbox One controller was my favorite. It has a great ergonomic design, nice feeling sticks, and a good weight. I pretty much thought that it was the perfect design for a controller.After I got the Pro Controller though, my opinions changed.The Pro Controller has a great ergonomic feel as well. The face of the controller is nice and large, and it has a matte finish to it. While the grip handles are a bit to small for my liking, the controls make up for it. The sticks feel has as good if not better than the Xbox controller's sticks, and I actually prefer the grip design of the Pro sticks. The Pro Controller face buttons are also miles better than the Xbox controller face buttons. While the Xbox buttons are only clicky, the Pro Controller buttons are nice and mushy, with a satisfying click at the end of the travel. The Pro Controller face buttons are also very large, which is something I didn't know I wanted.Other things that make the Pro better than the Xbox controller include: motion controls, heavier weight, and a better d-pad.That being said, the Pro Controller isn't perfect. While the aforementioned d-pad is better than the Xbox d-pad, it's still not great. The Pro is notorious for it's less than average d-pad. The size is a bit on the small side, and the d-pad is quite loose, which makes it prone to false inputs. Later revisions of the Pro Controller have improved on it though, and it's a least useable if nothing else.Overall though, I have to say that the Pro Controller has become my favorite controller to use. It's a shame that it really only works well on Nintendo Switch (it does have Bluetooth support for other devices, but you have to use external programs and the signal is prone to input lag), making it so that I can't use it on all devices.If you want the best controller experience on Switch, I think this controller definitely has to be on your final shortlist.
reviewTitle: My new favorite controller, so far!
name: Roberto H.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2020
reviewBody: Purchased this controller for my husband about 8 months ago. He was really into smash bro’s and BOTW at the time and his hands were getting fatigued from using the joycons. He absolutely loved the gift and uses it every time he decides to play. As an added bonus, I was able to reap the benefits from this controller when AC New Horizons came out. Overall, the quality of this controller is great and it is just as nice now as it was pre 2000 hours of play time. I would 100% recommend a pro controller to anyone that has a switch.
name: RW

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2019
reviewBody: An absolutely comfortable controller, one of the most so from Nintendo that I've used. I have normal sized hands but cannot stand how small the joycons are even attached to the holder. Has a great weight to it, D-pad is well made especially when compared to the joycon option. I especially like the feel of the ZL,ZR buttons, they fit the contour of where your fingers would be perfectly. It's a must for a second controller if needed, but it is my go to pad for playing everything, notably Smash Bros. Ultimate where a normal sized controller is more suited for. I find the joycons to feel extremely cheaply made, also evidenced by the rubber tops coming off after only a few months. Battery life is quite good on it as well, I really have nothing bad to say about it.
name: Michael P

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2020
reviewBody: I love this controller its comfortable to hold and it has a long battery life so I only have to charge maybe once a week which is great. They response feels very nice from the controller only thing to complain about is the price is some what expensive but I lucked out and got these for 55 dollars not pre owned but new. If you have money buy these but if you don't save up then purchase this because its worth it because joy con drift sucks... fix nintendo!!
name: Amazon Customer

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2019
reviewBody: The Switch Pro controller is an amalgamation of designs such as the Xbox 360 controller and the Dualshock 2. Having an outer ring, the analog sticks feel similar to the Dualshock 4's as well. The buttons are flat, as opposed to the convex buttons on microsoft controllers, which makes this more comfortable for me to press repeatedly. The back buttons are digital instead of triggers, which makes it more suitable to instant actions. I think this is the ideal controller for Bayonetta, and games like it.The D-Pad is outstanding given how generic in application this controller is. It is very slightly elevated in the center, meaning the hat switch is easy to rock back and forth. It doesn't hurt my thumb very much compared to a lot of previous Nintendo designs, but you may develop a callus if playing fighting games frequently.The controller's large button design can make it feel a bit clunky with some games, particularly in comparsion to playstation controllers. The placement of the D-Pad also is a bit unfortunate for games where you might want to use a claw grip on the left hand. Overall, this is a passable current generation controller to use when your switch is docked, certainly an improvement over joycons.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2020
reviewBody: I've had both one of my joycons and now my pro controller both experiences drift and make basically all games unplayable! reviewTitle: Nintendo Saying Joycon Drift isn't a problem is a lie!
name: Mark Miller

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2018
reviewBody: I have had the Switch for a year now, and the whole time I have been using the Joy-Con controllers in the grip, as I was surprised with how comfortable they were, even with my fairly large hands. I got the pro controller after my girlfriend moved in with me so we could play together more comfortably rather than using one Joy-Con each.I always thought the pro controller looked meh, as if the build quality would be distinctly average, but I was definitely wrong about that. It is exceedingly comfortable, and I mean the most comfortable controller I have ever used. It is as if Nintendo just decided to make the most ergonomic and functional controller they could, and they did just that. It does not look super flashy, but it is a damn fine controller. The buttons are big and comfortable, the controller sits nicely in the hand, the triggers are designed really well so they feel great and are natural to rest your fingers on.I know the controller is pricey, but if you play the Switch a fair bit at home docked, then its worth it. Great investment

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2019
reviewBody: Like other users, I’ve experienced issues with the left control stick. The first instance was with stick drift. I was surprised to have this issue because of the price. Luckily, the controller was under warranty. Nintendo repaired and sent it back at no cost to me.After a few more months of use the problem has returned. When I push the stick up, it comes back. Annoying when you’re tying to make a character run forward and they start walking. Again, my controller is under warranty so I sent it to Nintendo and they’re fixing it again.Other than that, the controller is great. But this problem makes it unusable. I fully expect this problem to happen again even after it’s “fixed.” I am disappointed that such an expensive controller would have this issue. Especially when controllers for other systems have stood the test of time. For now, I refuse to buy another pro controller. I will seek a third-party option.

name: Ghostman

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2020

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2020

It may be a bit expensive but it is a must!!

I have a third controller for the times when three of us want to play, but I probably should have just got another genuine Pro controller.
name: gary assassin

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2020

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2020

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2020

name: Saul E.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2019
reviewBody: Slightly expensive considering most PS4 and Xbox 1 controllers are 45 to 50 but it’s better than third party options. Solid option if you’re a solo gamer and like the traditional wireless controller feel. Here’s the build/design:• vibration mechanism like Xbox 1 with single unit in the middle• ZL and ZR more like L2 and R2 buttons on PS4 than actual triggers on Xbox 1• grips notably smaller than the PS4 but having the same joy-con setup (even lights for player number) makes up for it• single charging port limits your safe choices but I just leave the cable plugged into the side of the dockOverall a solid 4.5 of 5 but seeing as there isn’t much that’s better (for now) I’ll round it up to 5 because it charges quickly. Battery also lasts about as long as the joy-con pairs. Longer than the PS4 DualShock controller.
reviewTitle: Great but wait until price goes down
name: Mark A.

name: Keith

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2018
reviewBody: The price was indeed painful, but for what it is I think it's worth it.Here is why I think so:- Hours of battery life. There are people who says the battery lasts up to 40 hours, and in these last few months I don't doubt that.- The feel of it is so great. This is a 1000% step up from the joy on grip. Big to hold, nice solid responsive buttons.- DEFINITELY a step up from split joycons as you probably could have guessed. You can play multiplayer games with both joycons (I use them without grips), and the pro controller. Also, you can count the pro controller as a 3rd controller if two others use split joycons. So over all, an additional controller.These are the key reasons why I think the controller is worth the investment.Edit:I forgot to mention a very huge plus:The Pro controller pairs with the System as smoothly as the Joycons. reviewTitle: In my opinion, Pricey and worth it
name: Rodger Arnold

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2019
reviewBody: The Switch Pro controller is an amazing controller. I like everything about it, from the buttons to the analogue sticks. The HD rumble is great, and it's just the right size for my hands. And don't even get me started on the battery life. This thing's battery lasts so long that I often forget it even needs to be charged every once in a while.But I can't give it a full five stars. Reason being that the point where the analogue stick makes contact with the edges of the controller cause some serious abrasion. This has happened to both my pro controllers, and gives the analogue stick endpoints a slight grindy-ness for lack of a better term. It probably won't do anything serious to the controller's longevity, but it makes it lose its "premium" feel after about ten hours of use.I would love it if Nintendo offered an "elite" option like Microsoft does for the Xbox One. Even if it matched its price of $150, it would guarantee a premium-feeling controller that would maintain its premium feel for hundreds of hours of gameplay.

name: Peter Nunez

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2019
reviewBody: This is a really well built controller! I'll get right to the point about what I enjoy about this:* joysticks play really nicely, very smooth and accurate* Great grips! The controller feels like it melts into your hands. In contrast to just using the joycon (which don't have grips) , you can actually give this controller a death grip and still feel comfortable.* Not advertised, but it works well on the Steam client! (Nintendo doesn't endorse it) Valve developers have worked on drivers to make this controller work on all steam games.* Durability feels excellent. It feels like it will not break for another 10 - 15 years.* Dpad feels good, a great leg up from the Nintendo 3DS DPad. Due to greater thickness than any 3ds, the controller allows for a more bubbly feel when pressing down on the DPad. 99% of games I've played: Mutant Mudds, the NES Library, and Megaman 11 feel awesome. It will suit just about anything you throw at it.There is however one caveat to this controller, while the DPad is great, I wouldn't recommend it for something like Tetris where you require incredibly precise controls. For expert play, it's possible to accidentally harddrop a piece onto the board. I don't know many other games that require intense precision on all 4 corners of DPad, but be aware that the DPad can make the occasional mistake.I'm generally satisfied with this controller. I try to use it as often as possible, as I feel that the joycon feel a little easy to abuse :P
name: Zachary Mitchell

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2018
reviewBody: One of the most comfortable controllers I have ever used. It's size is roughly akin to that of an xbox one controller, but without the grooves, which works in its favor. I love the bigger size of the face buttons (XYAB), which i was originally skeptical about. It makes moving your thumb from the right stick very easy and fluid. The actual d-pad is a massive improvement over the joy-con controllers. The bumpers and triggers (L R and ZL ZR) are more or less 1:1 with the joy-cons. It did take me a small amount of time to get used to the position of the +. -, home and share buttons, but it hardly drew away from the overall controller experience. Additionally, you can use this controller for PC gaming via bluetooth if your computer supports it or a micro-usb cable, though you will need the proper drivers (which can be easily found online.).

name: Matt

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2019
reviewBody: I needed a controller as an alternative to my Joy Cons, as I have issues playing certain games with the tiny Joy Cons. The Pro Controller is a great controller, the buttons are big and responsive, it is very easy to connect to other Switch systems, and it's wireless so I can play in any comfortable position. Its battery life is half of most wireless controller from other systems, but I don't personally find it as an issue (you can just connect it though its usb cable and charge it while you play). A must-have controller if you like to play various games with a standard controller layout or multiplayer titles.
name: Jesus Sedano

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2017
reviewBody: Great looking controller with a nice heavy feel to it that makes it feel more durable in your hands. I didn't find the controller too heavy even after playing with it for hours. There was an adjustment period going from the Joy-Cons to the Pro controller but nothing an hour with the controller wouldn't fix. My only complaint is that the "+" and "-" buttons are square and feel like the home and share button. I wish they went with the design similar to the joy cons where the buttons were actually shaped like a + and -. All and all, a great controller if you are spending hours upon hours on games like Zelda BotW
name: Steven

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2018
reviewBody: It has a nice, ergonomic feel. My middle, ring, and pinky fingers feel right at home wrapped around the grips, unlike many other controllers for the console.Great stick height and nice buttons, but I wish they were in more of a diamond arrangement, instead of a rhombus.The triggers aren't analog triggers, just glorified buttons. Like, the GameCube had analog triggers, 3 console generations later and we're devolving? Slowing down at a corner in any racing game is no longer a tactic, it's a chore, not to mention the fact that it's less effective.D-pad is awful, do not recommend for fighting games or really any 2-D sidescrollers that take advantage of the diagonal inputs. It's as if the thing doesn't want to make inputs that are in any of the cardinal directions, because it always slides into a diagonal input unless I'm very careful to make sure it just goes in one direction. I literally had to hard-mod my controller just to make games like Celeste and SteamWorld Dig 2 playable.
reviewTitle: It has a nice, ergonomic feel
name: Benjer

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2019
reviewBody: I love this controller. The weight is good, controls are good, etc., but no matter what, the portion your hand actually grips, is always sticky. It's weird and it's because the grip portion is not made of the same material as the rest of it, and whatever they used is purposely sticky as in it makes you feel like your hands are dirty and sweaty even when they're dry and powdered. Not worth the money to be this uncomfortable.
name: don't you wish you knew

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2021
reviewBody: It is what is says it is. This is the best controller for the Switch. My son and I have gone through about 7-8 controllers. My son abuses it playing Fortnite and likes it -I think. He doesn't like to talk to me while he is playing. He gets mad at me and says "stop distracting me!". Do you think that is normal? Anyway, it is a very solid controller and I expect it to last a long time.
name: Mattjki

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2021
reviewBody: Absolutely no problems with this controller. My hands are on the medium size (8 inches all around my palm) but the controller is not too large. Triggers and buttons are much larger and responsive than stock joycon but the joystick took some time to get used to, I occasionally press in the joystick when playing intensely. Love the color and the charge holds forever. Have not had it run out me during a gaming session.
name: firstlast

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2020
reviewBody: This is a great controller! I've noticed it's much easier on your hands then joy con controllers. I don't know about quality yet, but we have had bad luck with our joy con controllers. The joy cons we have purchased seem very low quality. The knobs are glitchy and get stuck in forward and they do not want to connect with the switch sometimes. This controller seems to be working great so far. I will update if anything changes, though.
name: Mike

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2019
reviewBody: I was tired of taking the joy cons on and off to play games on my TV when the Switch is docked. This wireless controller is perfect for having a "normal" game experience with your Switch! The controller reminds me of an Xbox controller, so it wasn't hard to work it.You charge the controller through a USB cord you can connect to your Switch dock. The charge last a long time on the controller, at least for me it hasn't ran out yet haha! But I also replug it often so maybe that's why.No issues with this controller at all so 5 stars!
name: Some-Lady-Who-Reviews

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2019
reviewBody: It worked like a charm for the few days I actually got to use it. The left analog started to drift (sound familiar?) to the left making mariokart impossible. Come on Nintendo. I’ve heard this hundreds and hundreds of times, it’s obviously a problem. How about you fix this please. I can not recommend this controller especially at the price.lesson learned so you don’t have to.
reviewTitle: Left analog stick drift after a few days
name: Pauly

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2020
reviewBody: I was very surprised that the Nintendo Switch Pro Controller was usable wireless on PC, but once I figured that out it became my primary controller for everything. As an avid PC and console gamer I've used dozens of controllers over the years but have never had one that felt so natural one first picked up. The gyroscopes are an interesting feature and the button placement leads to easy combos. The battery life is fantastic and the sticks move smoothly.
name: Ray Thacher

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2020
reviewBody: Stopped working after 3 months - ironnically after the warrenty expires. Do NOT buy this controller because it will not last. Very disappointed because it was rather expensive.
name: Cyndi

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2018
reviewBody: I believe this is an essential to any Switch gamer that spends a lot of time with the console docked. It increases the ease of control that’s otherwise hindering with the small joy cons, and it lets the joy cons charge for later portable use. I find it especially useful for Mario tennis aces, or any game where the right control stick is used. I find myself accidentally bumping it and messing up my game on the joy cons. My only gripe is that the control sticks have a type of rim around them that hurts if you play hard like me. (I actually got a blister on my thumb after only a few hours of play.) Note: I also have a blue cover on my controller and a control stick cover to alleviate the aforementioned issue, and it seems to have worked.
reviewTitle: Makes gaming easier, not so easy on the thumbs
name: Aliwch

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2020
reviewBody: i bought 3rd party controllers which didn't connect wirelessly to switch no matter what i did. so i used them with cable connection but it often dropped the connection. i gave this controller a try. i was hesitant at first because of the price but what a difference it made! it connected to switch without any issues for the first try. it doesn't drop the connection and it works great. it is definitely worth the price.
reviewTitle: it works great, connects wirelessly without any issues
name: Sasuke

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2020
reviewBody: Used this controller for a few hours for Animal Crossing then on the next day, the left joystick had drifting problems. Probably a bad batch, and needs to be returned.**Update**With the latest system update which is supposed to fix the joystick problem, and after resetting my controller to factory settings and desyncing then resyncing it, the problem is fixed now. Changed my rating from 1 star to 4 stars. It's weird to me how this was a software issue, but glad it's fixed. :)
name: Annie

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2019
reviewBody: When you take the NFC, accelerometer, and vibration into account this controller is a steal. However I wish nintendo made a cheaper version without the NFC for the other 3 controllers I would buy for multiplayer. Amibbos are cool but most games don't use them and if I don't own any why would I buy hardware to support them?The accelerometer is amazing in BoTW. Wish we had some real shooters here like cod to really make use of this fine tuning for shooting
reviewTitle: Well worth the price tag that at first I thought was rather high
name: Alex

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2019
reviewBody: This controller is overall highly rated, and with good reason. I'll explain further:Pros:Solid designDecent weightFeels naturalRidiculous battery life (40 hours of play time for a 6-hour charge)It is a much better gaming experience on the television than the dual-con gripVery smooth, precise joysticksDpad is actually practical compared to the joycons designLarge buttonsCons:Rather on the expensive side ($56 at the time of the post, however, it used to be $70)Not suitable for more handheld inclined playersRequires separate charging port (USB, included on the dock)Overall, it is a great controller, and I believe that some will enjoy it. It is a bit pricy, but if you consistently play on your TV and want a great, comfortable, and immersive experience with Smash Ultimate or Breath of the Wild, this is for you.
name: LCC

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2019
reviewBody: It's so much more comfortable in my hand than the joycon is I feel more freedom of movement I have long fingers and when I use the joy con I can almost completely wrap my hand all the way around it and touch my wrist the Pro controller I don't have that problem save up your money and get one you won't be disappointed yeah it's a little on the expensive side but even if you can go to Etsy you can get a 3D printed holder so that you can mount your switch screen on top of the controller. How's that for ease of access lol
name: kevin clyde

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2020
reviewBody: Been gaming all my life, I go through controllers like you wouldn't believe. This is the nicest controller i've ever used on any system. Comfortable design, smooth joysticks, responsive buttons. I just wish I could use this on my PC and playstation. My only complaint is that just like the charger on the switch, it can only be a NINTENDO usb charger. Why the hell make a UNIVERSAL-serial-bus plug that's...not universal?
name: Corey Griffin

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2020
reviewBody: The controller arrived almost 3 days quicker than anticipated. Not only that but for a Used Like New it was practically a new controller never opened complete with plastic film over the front display. I really lucked out getting this considering I have been camping for near a year for the price to drop under $90 thanks to scalpers.The controller itself is very solid and being a Xenoblade fan, I can see myself using this for years to come.Great Product.
name: Amazon Customer

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2017
reviewBody: If you have a switch, you need this controller. I waited for a few months after I got my switch to purchase, mainly due to no stock available. But man I am so glad I got it, it just feels perfect. Don’t let the price turn you away, the battery life is extremely good, I play my switch a lot and charge it once every 3-4 weeks, compared to my ps4s once every 2 days. It has the motion controls, rumble, amiibo reader. USB c charging cable is a nice touch too.
name: Blade

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2020
reviewBody: To those of you who have experienced the dreaded joy con drift like me, this is the perfect substitute. I read a suggestion to get the pro controller rather than a new pair of joy cons as it'd be less of a risk of having the same problem as joy-cons.UPDATE: 3 months in and no problems. Works well with my fast paced rhythm games.
name: Erica Hester

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2018
reviewBody: I've used things like Scuffs, the Xbox Elite controller, etc, so my standards are pretty high. I'd gotten so used to the Joycons and clawing while I was waiting for this. It's... alright. Pretty standard controller, nothing outstanding. No bells and whistles, no paddles, no button remapping. Doesn't offer anything the joycons don't outside of ergonomics and a standardized form-factor. I'd love to see if Scuff eventually releases a switch controller.
name: Garrett K. Bemis

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2018
reviewBody: At first, I was a little hesitant to buy the Pro Controller (price, obviously) for my Switch, but I caved and bought it from Amazon anyway. Once I received it, holy cow, I was impressed! The buttons, joysticks, and motions are very responsive. The vibrations from the HD rumble is really detailed, unlike anything I've experienced from my past controllers. The battery lasts a long time, I was playing Mario Kart 8 and Odyssey for a few hours every day for a few weeks before I finally had to recharge it. I cannot give you my answer on the NFC touchpoint, because I don't own an Amiibo, yet. The only issue I have is that Nintendo should make the home and capture buttons stand out a little more, so I don't have to keep looking down at my controller when my thumb couldn't find one of them.If you're looking to buy a regular controller for your Switch, I recommend getting the Pro Controller!
name: TheAceOfCubs

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2018
reviewBody: This controller is pretty good for people wanting an improvement over the Joy-Cons that come with the console. It has almost all of the features the Joy-Cons had (there's no IR sensor), it feels pretty good (doesn't feel cheap at all!), and it has a great battery life. Compared to the Switch's included Joy-Cons, this controller is larger and has a directional pad. Overall, it's a very fantastic controller.However, if you're buying more than one, the price adds up rather dramatically, as they cost $60-$70 each. If you want a cheaper (but still great) alternative, PowerA makes Nintendo-certified USB controllers for under half the price, though these do lack motion control and rumble.
reviewTitle: Great controller but do you actually want this?
name: Snowy

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2020
reviewBody: Love using this as my primary controller. Light in my hands but still a solid build quality. Allows me to save on banging up the original Joy Cons to prevent the very well known drifting issue.
name: F. Leigh

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2018
reviewBody: This is a perfect controller if you're planning on long gaming sessions, or if you want to play shooters and more fast-paced games. The sticks are easier to manipulate than on the joycons, giving you better control, and the whole thing feels a bit more comfortable than just holding the two small halves.That said, if you don't feel like you need finer control for your games, the only real benefit over the joycons is battery life. As long as you don't mind putting the controllers back on the Switch after each play session, that's not a huge issue.
reviewTitle: A better option for long play sessions or shooters
name: Eddie Dring

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2017
reviewBody: I'm one of those people that rarely has time to game on the go. My Switch will be used at home, connected to my tv, 99% of the time. I found the included Joycon controller, to be a little small for my hands, so i bought the Pro. Right off the bat, you notice how much more comfortable it is to hold for extended periods of time, over the joycons. The inclusion of a proper D-Pad, is also a plus, as i found the 4 buttons on the joycon that act as the D-Pad, just felt weird, when i tried to use what should've been a D-Pad. The buttons and thumbsticks, just seem to react better overall. The battery life of the Pro, is really long. Somewhere around 40 hours, off of 1 charge. I only own Zelda BOTW so far, so i can't comment on the rumble feature, as Zelda barely uses it, and i also can't comment on the built in Amiibo scanner, as i have yet to use it, since i don't have any Amiibo. In the end, if you game mostly at home like myself, definitely get yourself the Pro controller, for extended periods of play.
reviewTitle: Much Better Than Joycons, For Home Use.
name: Bill B.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2021
reviewBody: I love this wireless controller. I've found that it has plenty of battery life and I love that I can just plug it into my Switch to charge when I'm not using it. It's easy to use and comfortable to hold. Makes my gaming experience a little easier too. A+
reviewTitle: Good battery life, makes gaming easier
name: Ashley Watters

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2020
reviewBody: I like buying official Nintendo brand on things. The battery lasts a really long time. Since buying I still haven’t charged it. It does come with a charging wire just plugs into a USB port. The hand grip is very comfortable for long game time. I am enjoying playing my switch games in a different more comfortable way. I do wish they had different colors to choose from like the joy cons.
name: Angel

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2019
reviewBody: This controller is great, just like the Wii U pro controller (would have been great to be able to re-use those!).The battery life and feel of the controller is good, and I would recommend getting this as your 2nd or 3rd switch purchase after a couple of good games. It feels much more precise than using the switch joycons either attached or detached.The price is too high, but that is always the case with Nintendo's products, and for that reason this controller only gets 4 stars instead of 5.
name: JCS

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2018
reviewBody: I had no problem with the Joycon grip when playing the Switch in docked mode but I was able to get a Pro controller at a great discount so I picked one up. It's a great controller! I've had it for a couple months and I've yet to recharge the battery, very impressive. If you primarily play your Nintendo Switch on TV, I highly recommend getting the Pro Controller.
reviewTitle: Great purchase for those who play Switch on TV frequently
name: Alex Harker

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2017
reviewBody: Feels completely different from the Joycons. Stronger joysticks, buttons, and triggers. Feels like far more is put into controller feel than anything else. Battery lasts pretty long. Almost as long as the Wii U Pro controllers. These feel more hand gripping and slightly higher quality than the Wii U ones. Only thing I can complain about is that I wish that they looked better. I highly suggest this controller if you play a lot of games on your TV and not in portable mode.
name: T.T.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2020
reviewBody: This controller is amazing. It feels so good in your hands. The battery life on this controller is insane compared to the PS4 controller. This controller lasts like 20+hours of game play on a single charge. One of the reasons why it's so good is because it does not have an annoying big bright light in the back of it to lower the battery charge as quickly *cough* PS4 *cough*....If you want of a more classical feel controller then get this for your Switch. It's the only and BEST option.
name: Taylor S.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2020
reviewBody: The ergonomics of this controller are some of the best I've ever had for a controller in my life.But the D-pad is nearly worthless. It will randomly trigger the wrong direction, or even trigger other buttons (the L-button in particular). This makes a lot of games unplayable, like Crypt of the Necrodancer or Cadence of Hyrule.I've heard this problem is endemic to the controller design itself.
name: Christopher Swenson

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2020
reviewBody: I bought this as a bundle with Zelda. Saved a few bucks but just be cautious with the first gen pro controllers because they have an inaccurate dpad. Check online for the newer model serial number. It's ok though because this is my shell change SNES controller so its imperfect as my daily beater. If you can't live with the dpad being perfect, I suggest going out your way to finding the newer model. If MSRP is already 70 and taking this for 50, that's ok for me but this is a licensed Nintendo's ,"Pro Controller" ; knowing this should be a quality product. That's my two cents.
reviewTitle: Beware of the dpad, can be faulty...
name: Benz Dela Guardia

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2018
reviewBody: D-pad aside, this is the most slick controller ive held in a long time. It's dinput compatible, so it will work with your PC. It also works natively with the steamlink now.Unfortunately, the charge port is only for charging. Most Android flavours have difficulty with it, it will work fine at first but then lag. probably a polling issue. This is almost a non issue aside from a few games that benefit.
reviewTitle: Probably the best controller this generation.
name: RJ

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2017
reviewBody: If you own a Switch this is a MUST HAVE. It is the most comfortable controller I have ever held Nintendo did their home work here think Gamecube controller but even more comfortable. I can't say enough about this just get it.
reviewTitle: It is the most comfortable controller I have ever held Nintendo did their home ...
name: N. Black

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2017
reviewBody: I love how comfortable this controller is. It feels great.I have yet to run out of battery. I can game all day, and not worry about running low on power.The only problem I have with this controller is that its analog sticks often overshoot center when released from their extremes. This results in Link throwing a lot of his bombs away from the monsters he is battling, and it is highly frustrating. It can be minimized if actively making manual efforts, but I would much rather fully concentrate on the game.The controller looks cool, the way that the reinforcements can be seen through the plastic. There is also a fun, well-hidden message which can be found if you look close enough.
reviewTitle: The Self Centering Analog Sticks Overshoot
name: J. Sullivan

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2020
reviewBody: The feel and durability of the Pro Controller is way better than Joy Cons, and is a must have for playing on the TV. However, after about ~800 hrs of smash and other games, my left joy stick began to drift/picking up bad responses. Sad, because it is an incredibly comfortable controller and I like it way more than the GC controller for Smash.Still better durability than the Joy Cons, but not up to Nintendo's standards as far as older gen controllers (GC controller)
reviewTitle: Better than Joy Cons, still has drift issues.
name: Shawn

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2018
reviewBody: Looks gorgeous! Feels like the regular one just with a design and looking prettier than the regular one. It's worth getting one, or even two.
name: Juan Torres

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2018
reviewBody: Build quality and comfort is very good. Not sure I would put the controller above the Xbox One or the PS4, but easily the best Nintendo controller ever made IMO. The sicks are sensitive and very accurate. The buttons are a pleasure to press without the numbing feeling you can get from some of the rounded hard plastic buttons. Price is a little high, so have held my purchase to just one of these. Wish they were less, so I could sport a pair, but they aren't so I wont :(.
reviewTitle: Build quality and comfort is very good. Not sure I would put the controller above ...
name: Amazon Customer

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2021
reviewBody: This so much nicer than the joy cons. It feels really solidly built, similar to the new XBox controllers. While it is expensive, once you use it you won’t want to go back. A few reviews commented that the triggers are not analog, which is true. However the games are not set up for analog input so it doesn’t matter.
name: Jessica

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2021
reviewBody: I had bought a cheaper controller to use with my grandson to play games with him but it only worked for two weeks. Then I purchased this Nintendo one and it has worked well. My advice is to avoid the temptation to buy one of the cheap knock-offs and just go straight for the more expensive Nintendo one. In the end you will save money and be happy.
name: Thomas Siefert

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2018
reviewBody: The controller is my favorite to use across my switch and PC. The price may be a bit expensive, but the fact it is rechargeable and runs for around 50 hrs on a single charge is well worth it in my opinion. The controller has a good weight and feel that I can play for hours whether it be rocket league, or an adventure game such as Zelda: BoTW. Steam works well with it either hard wired connected or via Bluetooth, allowing you to customize every button to be what you wish.It connects and charges via the same usb-c the switch charges with, and includes a usb -> usb-c cable if you would want to charge it off of the switch dock as well.I've only had one trouble with the device itself, it randomly stopped working/charging one day (approximately 3-4 months after buying it), but after calling Nintendo they happily sent me free shipping labels and repaired it free of charge.
reviewTitle: Worth the price, and it feels pretty nice.
name: Adam P.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2020
reviewBody: So I've been trying to get a good cheap switch controller for a couple years, and all of the ones I got (including powerA) only lasted around 6 months before issues start appearing. I eventually got fed up with buying new controllers and went all in on a pro controller. When I got to the first one I ordered, the controller felt weighty and obviously high quality. HOWEVER, DAY ONE, not even 5 minutes in, the left stick drifts down. Returned and got a new one. This one drifts down on both sticks. I know this is a great product, but if you want to get one online, be prepared to return it.Edit: got a third one, still drifts right out of the package
name: Rebekah

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2021
reviewBody: My brother has picked up his Switch again and quickly realized that he still preferred an Xbox type controller. I recommended him the Pro Controller, and it has quickly turned his gameplay around. He hasn't experienced any drifting as he does with the joycons, and we both like that the buttons feel more sturdy in the hand.
name: Mary C.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2018
reviewBody: I like everything about the actual use of the controller.. There are 2 big irritating things about it.1. Because the battery is internal.. If it's dead, your out of luck in terms of swapping a battery.2. You may see the cable type is usbc and think.. Great my other chargers can charge this! Nope, ONLY THE NINTENDO CAN. STUPID STUPID STUPID!
name: Daniel Brown

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2017
reviewBody: This is a must have if you have a Switch. The controller feels way better than those puny Joycons. It's got a good weight to it and very good quality controller. If you play Splatoon you gotta get this or you cant paint as effectively, resulting in losing all the time. The NFC scanning works great and fast too. Just touch the Amiibo to the center of the controller and it will work some magic.
reviewTitle: Well worth the price to pwn some noobs
name: Chao Chao

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2018
reviewBody: It's going to take some time to get used to the weight and shoulder buttons on this compared to the Joy Con. The buttons have softer feedback than the very mechanical feeling Joy Cons, and I'm not sure which I prefer. Pairing was quick and painless, very ergonomic, all the added functions, such as motion controls and amiibo reader are all present (I haven't had a good chance to tell if the HD rumble is present, or just a more basic rumble feature). If the battery life is as good on this as it was the Wii U's Pro Controller, then It'll be half a year before I have to give it it's first charge.
name: Patrick Frentz

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2020
reviewBody: This controller is very durable and most importantly comfortable! This is tied with the steam controller for my favorite. It's joysticks have a smooth responsive feel with a great shape and textured grip. The handles feel good even after long play sessions and the buttons have a superior feel and click without being loud like the joy-cons.
name: LSDJay

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019
reviewBody: This is right up there, right above the xbox one controller as the most comfortable ever for me. The triggers have a much nicer pull and click feel to me, though they're more linear than the xbox one. The buttons are all wonderful to feel and the control sticks have a great rubber that offers grip but with no additional texture. It's a bit expensive though, possibly because of the amiibo reader which i think is unnecessary, but if you can get this controller, it's wonderful for the switch. Battery lasts quite a long while and can be used wired if needed
name: BlueJay Gyphon

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2017
reviewBody: As soon as I held the controller in my hands, I could feel the great build quality of it. All buttons feel great and are highly responsive. The analog sticks feel incredibly smooth. Motion controls are responsive. The HD rumble feels nice on the controller. Only the D-pad leaves a bit to be desired, while it feels nice, there are times where it'll read up-left when I was just pressing up, for example. However, it isn't enough to make me regret my purchase.
reviewTitle: Great controller, D-pad not so great.
name: Trvial

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2019
reviewBody: D-pad aside, this controller is great for most games on the Switch. It's most used while docked on my TV, and for an extra controller during local multiplayer.However the majority of my Switch use is in handheld mode. So I don't use this controller a whole lot.Once I buy a Switch display arm, so I can dock it onto my wall and adjust the screen location where I want, while in bed, I will likely use this controller more.
reviewTitle: I like how this feels in my hands, but it is big to haul around.
name: Mark "The Giant"

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2019
reviewBody: I love my Pro controller, so when the joysticks were going bad and I needed to replace it, I wasn't willing to switch to any of the other gamepads. While I could have torn it apart and replaced the joysticks, I figured it was time to get a second one anyway, and pulled the trigger on this one. I'll fix the first one later, in the meantime, I still have my favorite controller on hand. Zero complaints (except, perhaps, inability to hold up to a year of gaming before needing new joysticks).
name: Hectate

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2021
reviewBody: Wish I'd gotten this controller sooner. Bought it out of frustration over constantly drifting Joy Cons (even brand new ones that weren't even a month old) and this thing is clearly just SO much sturdier. It also feels really cozy in my hands. Much prefer to play games with this beast than the fragile Joy Cons.
name: Yuuna V.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2020
reviewBody: Best Switch Controller, hands down. Pricey, but worth it. Was glad to grab a second one on sale from Amazon because tired of fighting my wife for just the one. These things rock compared to the cheap feel of the joy cons.
reviewTitle: A MUST own for switch players
name: Cameron M

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2017
reviewBody: +It's very comfortable to hold and feels substantial in your hands. I want to stress how solid this controller feels and the build quality behind it. I can twist the grips pretty aggressively and they don’t give or make noise. In comparison Sony and Microsoft’s controllers creak and feel like they’ll break from noticeably thinner and weaker plastic.+The analog sticks are very comfortable, have little friction, and the edges have a nice grippy pattern. After 2000 hours of Splatoon 2 the analog sticks return to neutral and there’s no wobbling or drifting. The sticks do rub against the sides though and will produce some plastic dust. One disappointing problem I ran into was occasionally the right stick would register a click despite not being pressed down.+It uses USB-C and comes with 1 Nintendo branded USB-A to USB-C cable about 5 feet in length. Plugging it in to your Switch will instantly sync the controller.+It lasts 40 hours. That's not impressive compared to the Wii U's Pro Controller at 80 hours, but it's still going to make it near impossible to run out of juice if you're addicted to Zelda. The controller feature gyroscopes, HD Rumble, and NFC which reduce battery life.+The area your fingers get into contact with are matte, and you won't have to worry about scratches, fingerprints, or other blemishes if you take care of it.+I clean my hands religiously, but on other controllers, oils would still build up and get into the cracks and it’s pretty disgusting. I’ve had only extremely minor oil build up on this controller. Maybe the plastic is coated in an oleophobic coating? It’s strange, but that’s possibly the most impressive thing I can say about this controller.+You can use the controller on a PC as a generic input device. It does not work over USB and requires Bluetooth.-The only part the controller that is glossy plastic is at the top of the controller which comes shipped covered in a plastic protective sheet. This also happens to be where the USB cable plugs in. It’s going to get scratched. It might look nice, but functionally this is foolish. Why would you make the only area where the metal could come into contact with controller the one spot that could get easily scratched?-The D-Pad registers false inputs when pressed. As of this review, Nintendo has refused to acknowledge this design defect. It makes playing Puyo-Puyo Tetris and Tetris 99 impossible since pressing Up makes pieces drop instantly.-The L and R bumpers have a very small area we’re pressing them won’t register an input well. If you use the outer edges you probably will never run into this but it’s still worth mentioning.-The Share and Home buttons are way too close and similar in shape to the + or - button, and there's no intuitive way to feel for which you're pressing. It’s too bad they aren’t + and - shaped like on the JoyCons.-The Switch has an option to use the controller wired for reduced input latency, but for most people this is rather useless unless you buy a much longer cord.-There's no analog triggers, but that's because it has parity with the JoyCons. Still not an excuse and would have made this item far more valuable if supported.-I had a harder time feeling HD Rumble on this than the JoyCons. It's a subtle effect, but given the size and rigid nature of this controller, it really should have been amped up overall.-It's $70 MSRP. That's not only more than a game, it's more than the competitors. I know controllers are more complicated than ever and its build quality is far superior with the exception of the D-Pad, but that doesn’t make it any easier to swallow.Children and smaller handed people can probably get by with Joy-cons. If you find them too small, this controller will be a welcome bit of comfort.I have personally gotten a lot of use and enjoyment out of it, especially with Splatoon 2. The only reason I’m giving it three stars is because I expect more responsibility and the highest quality from Nintendo products. One of the major reasons to invest in this controller is the D-Pad. Nintendo practically invented the modern D-Pad. That they’ve allowed this defect to exist and be denied is a travesty.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2020
reviewBody: Ah, the Switch, what a console. It has tons of great games, both for casual and competitive players, tons of great multiplayer options, and lots of neat bells and whistles. Arguably its greatest feature is the ability to play it either docked to your TV or in hand held mode, and both feel great. All the buttons are easy to reach, and feels good to hold, so good build quality all around. It hooks up easily (you'll probably need to charge it first) and once hooked up, it stays hooked up until I switch it to something else. I've never had a problem with it randomly disconnecting.The one problem I have had is that on rare occasions, the left stick gets stuck in the down position. When this happens, it is easy to pop back out and stops after a few minutes. IF this was a common problem, I'd have to dock a star, but because it only happens occasionally and not all the time, no stars lost.Overall, fantastic controller, and a must for serious switch players. reviewBody: Before you even consider buying one of these, Google "Switch Pro Controller Left Joystick Drift" (you won't need to type much since it's a top fill result...). Googling the issue and hoping it was just a calibration thing or something, it's clear Nintendo used faulty equipment in the Pro controller, and it seems to be specifically bad on the left joystick. Nintendo only puts a 90 day warranty on these, which clearly means they know they're garbage and don't stand behind their hardware at all. I'm extremely disappointed, and done with Nintendo brand accessories. If I'm going to get faulty trash, I may as well buy 3rd party for 1/3 of the money. By the way, after 3 months, Nintendo will charge you $50 to "fix" your faulty controller, and ship you back another faulty piece a month later. They've known they're faulty for years and continue using the same known-bad switches and sensors. Avoid at all costs.

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2020
reviewBody: The controller feels fantastic in your hands. This is especially apparent after trying to use the tiny joycons with their even tinier buttons and joysticks. If your an adult with moderate to large hands you need this controller. Playing games like Resident Evil 5 or Doom feel worlds better with a controller that is designed for hands larger than a 10 year old's. Using the controller mount for the joycons is not a substitute for a pro controller. After using the pro controller, you realize that the joycon's tiny buttons, joysticks, and shoulder buttons are things you tolerate. Even if you decide against buying this controller (most likely due to the price), buy a cheaper third party traditional controller. Comfort - 10/10The buttons are large, which I love, reminding more of the larger buttons seen on the original SNES controller. The buttons along with the D-pad have a matte finish that feel great. A special mention of the D-pad must be made. This D-pad feels fantastic. Compared to the 8bitdo SN30 pro, it is NO CONTEST. The D-pad for Nintendo's pro controller is top of the line and blows the third party D-pads out of the water. The Joysticks feel good, maybe even great. They have raised edges with ridges for increased grip which feel good on your thumbs. I still prefer the concave shape of the Xbox One joysticks but the switch pro controller joysticks are comfortable, responsive, and accurate. Compared to the Wii U pro controller, the joysticks feel less sturdy though. The Wii U pro controller feel sturdy and require more effort to move them, which I like. This is not a big deal but I feel some may not like joysticks that have less resistance. Buttons and Joysticks - 9/10When it come to the value, the switch pro controller is a sea of grey. It really depends on the value you place on each individual feature found in the pro controller. The third party enhanced switch controllers are around 20$ cheaper and feel close to the same but lack many of the features the pro controller has (it doesn't even have basic rumble). You can also find even cheaper controllers that don't have even the most basic features of a pro controller but are still fine controllers if all your looking for is a comfortable gaming experience for your hands. I like the HD rumble and motion controls and would like to have the convenience of amiibo support (even though I don't really see it lasting much longer) so I don't mind paying the 70$. Nintendo's controllers are also known for lasting forever, so you most likely won't need to buy another one for the rest of your life (I still use the gamecube and Wii U pro controllers I got at the launches). Overall Value - 8/10

postDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2017
reviewBody: The Nintendo Switch Pro Controller is very well built, it's comfortable, has some weight to it and has textured grips to keep the controller from slipping out of your hands. There's no creaking or bending of the controller while playing, It's the alternative choice for those who want a more traditional way to play games compared to the Joy-Cons setup with the standard Attachment or Charging Grip. It comes with a USB-C cable and can be charged from the Switch docking station or AC adapter.It's an overall improvement over the Wii U Pro Controller, ditching the odd right joystick placement and moving it below the primary buttons, resembling a Xbox controller. It also has larger trigger buttons up top and larger X, A, Y, B buttons which are certainly welcome but it does still lack the pressure sensitive secondary analog triggers that both the Xbox One and PlayStation 4 controllers have - I personally like having that when it comes to racing games. The analog sticks feel smooth and rise slightly around their circumference to prevent your thumbs from slipping off. The classic D-pad makes a return again on the Pro-Controller, It's the same size as the d-pad on the Wii and Wii U Pro Controllers. It feels responsive and has the solid quality clicks you've come to expect from Nintendo controllers but I found that in a few instances, I've accidently click one direction when pressing another, thankfully it doesn't happen to me all the time but it could be improved. The + and - button placements are easier to use compared to the Joy-Con setup and are more in reach this time around compared to the Wii U Pro Controller but I wish the buttons would protrude outward more like the Wii U Pro Controller. While playing and without looking down at the controller, I find myself feeling around the for the + or - buttons because they sit almost flush with the controller face and it makes them somewhat difficult to press. The Screenshot and Home buttons also sit very flush and sometimes I'll accidently end up pressing them instead of the - and + buttons.The battery life is phenomenal, I can't remember the last time I plugged in the Pro Controller to charge it up. It can hold a charge for 40 hours and takes 4-5 hours to fully recharge. The Controller has the advertised "HD Rumble" that's been featured with the Joy-Con controllers. As far as I could tell—with the handful of games I've tried—the rumble feedback functions about the same as it does with the Joy-Cons. It also has Motion Sensors and built-in Amiibo functionality, you can place the Amiibo figure on top of the switch icon of the controller to scan it.It connects to the Switch via Bluetooth so you can easily use this controller on your home computers or smart phone as well. I've had some trouble getting it to connect on Windows 7 but then I tried Windows 10 and it was as simple as having your PC search for a BT device while holding the sync button on top of the controller for 3 seconds. Once the controller is properly synced, you can use it just like any other Bluetooth controller. Initially, I had some issues getting the Pro Controller to connect to my Switch but since then, it's been connecting every single time, one push of the Home Button and it takes 2 seconds.Just like the Joy-Cons, the bottom of the Pro Controller has four LEDs that represent which player it's set to(starting from the left) and if it's properly connected to the system. It is a pricey controller, at this point it cost $69 and that makes it a good $15-20 more expensive then it's competitors. It currently does not have a headphone/mic jack.Comfort wise, It could possibly be the most comfortable controller out there. Sometimes I even forget I'm still holding it when gaming for a while. If you own a Nintendo Switch and want a more traditional way to play your games that provides a proper d-pad, larger primary buttons, ergonomic shoulder buttons, extremely long battery life and is very comfortable to hold.. the Switch Pro Controller is certainly a step-up from your Joy-Cons.

After a while, the joysticks get scraped from grinding against the side of the socket that they're in. No problem right? Well it wouldn't be if it didn't produce plastic dust that gets into the controller. That dust will eventually make it so your joystick starts to drift while playing. For mine, it drifts downward. I've opened it and cleaned it multiple times and it keeps happening.I would stay away from this controller unless it goes on a HEAVY sale or they fix the issues with it.
